question.text: Which of the following best describes the role of T-cells in the immune system?

explanation.concept_text: T cells are a type of leukocyte (white blood cell) that are an essential part of the immune system. T cells originate in the bone marrow and mature in the thymus. In the thymus, each T cell multiplies and differentiates into one of four types of T cells: helper, cytotoxic, regulatory, or memory T cell. They are then sent to peripheral tissues or circulate in the blood or lymphatic system. Every T cell has a unique T cell receptor (TCR) that can bind to only one kind of antigen. Once stimulated by the appropriate antigen, each T cell carries out its respective function. Helper T cells (aka CD4 T cells) secrete chemical messengers called cytokines , which stimulate the differentiation of B cells into plasma cells that produce antibodies. Regulatory T cells act to control immune reactions through negative feedback. Memory T cells provide long-term protection against specific antigens and proliferate once the antigen is detected again. T cells are crucial in the immune system’s cell-mediated immunity. A Cell-mediated response is an immune response that does not involve antibodies. Rather, a cell-mediated response is the activation of phagocytes, antigen-specific cytotoxic T-lymphocytes, and the release of various cytokines in response to an antigen. On the other hand, humoral immunity is carried out by antibodies floating in bodily fluids (humors = body fluids) to eliminate extracellular pathogens. The difference between cell-mediated and humoral immunity is also illustrated in the image below, where T-Cells are mainly involved in Cell-mediated immunity. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Cause humoral responses – This option is incorrect because the role of the T-cells involves cell-mediated immunity. They are not involved in humoral responses such as antibody release. It is important to distinguish between the two types of adaptive immunity: humoral immunity and cell-mediated immunity. Humoral immunity produces antigen-specific antibodies that circulate in bodily fluids to neutralize and eliminate extracellular pathogens. This is driven by B cells. On the other hand, cell-mediated immunity does not depend on antibodies to function and instead uses mature T cells to directly address intracellular pathogens. Option C. Create antibodies – This option is incorrect because creating antibodies is a part of humoral immunity which involves B-cells. Recall that an alternate name for this immune response is antibody-mediated immunity. T-cells are not involved in this process but, rather, are involved in cell-mediated immunity such as initiating cell death (apoptosis) in infected cells or causing cell lysis using perforin. Option D. Can engulf foreign bodies – This option is incorrect because the engulfment of foreign bodies is known as phagocytosis which is done by cells of the innate immune system, specifically, monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, dendritic cells, and mast cells. T-cells are not involved in this process as they are a part of the adaptive immune system and have roles in cell-mediated immunity. Instead, T cells eliminate pathogens by initiating programmed cell death (apoptosis) in infected cells or causing cell lysis using perforin. Option E. Release histamine – Histamine is a chemical that is crucial for the formation of inflammation. Histamine is released in response to an injury, and it causes nearby capillaries to dilate which then increases blood flow and blood vessel permeability. This opens the way for immune cells and nutrients to address the injury. This option is incorrect because histamine is released by mast cells and basophils. T-cells are not involved in the release of histamine and are instead involved in cell-mediated immunity such as the killing of infected cells.

question.text: All of the following species have segmentation EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Segmentation is the repetition of similar organs, tissues, cell types, or body cavities along the anterior-posterior axis of symmetric animals. Without segmentation, organisms would lack complex means of movement and complex body structures that enable advanced functions. More specifically, segmentation provides the means for an organism to travel and protect its sensitive organs from damage. Segmentation also provides the ability to divide functions into different portions of the body and allow an organism to perform increasingly complex activities and use different segments to perform varying functions. Additionally, segmentation allows for a greater degree of variety among species. Some common organisms that are segmented include arthropods, annelids, chordates, and vertebrates. Body segmentation is controlled by Hox genes. These genes are responsible for the early morphogenesis (body formation) of many animal embryos. Specifically, they control the body position and placement of the anatomic structures in a developing embryo. In other words, these genes provide the instructions that place the head at the top of the body and the feet at the bottom, as opposed to any other possible combination. If the Hox genes are absent or mutated, the embryo will develop with misplaced body parts and is unlikely to survive. Moreover, Hox genes are highly conserved in plants, animals, and fungi. That is, they have remained mostly unchanged throughout their multi-species evolution. This multi-species relationship is illustrated in the image below. To answer this question, it may be helpful to first visualize all the animal phyla in order of least to most complex (i.e., Porifera and Cnidaria through Chordata) and realize that, generally, the less complex the body of a Phylum, the less chance there is for segmentation . For example, given that Phyla with bilateral symmetry are more complex than those with radial symmetry or no symmetry at all, it makes sense that segmentation can be found only in Phyla with bilateral symmetry. Using these two pointers can aid your process of elimination for this question. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Arthropods – Recall that, as seen in the image above, the classic example of body segmentation and Hox genes is that of a fruit fly, which is an arthropod. This option is incorrect because arthropods such as spiders and insects DO have segmentation because their body parts are divided into discrete sections with specific functions such as the head, thorax, abdomen, etc. Option C. Annelids – This answer option might be tempting given that Annelids are not as complex as Arthropods or Chordates in body structure. However, this option is incorrect because annelids such as earthworms DO exhibit bilateral symmetry and they DO have segmentation as their body parts are divided into discrete sections. Thus, Annelids are more complex in body structure when compared to option A, Cnidaria. Option D. Vertebrates – This option is incorrect because vertebrates such as humans and other mammals have bilateral symmetry and they DO have segmentation as their body parts are divided into discrete sections with specific sections such as the head, thorax, abdomen, etc. Recall that vertebrates are part of the Phylum Chordates, which is the most complex phylum given their highly specialized organs and tissue. This increased complexity in body structure should be another pointer that vertebrates exhibit segmentation. Option E. Chordates – This option is incorrect because chordates such as humans and other mammals have bilateral symmetry and they DO have segmentation as their body parts are divided into discrete sections with specific sections such as the head, thorax, abdomen, etc. Recall again that Chordates are the most complex Phylum, thus this should be one of the first options to be eliminated.

question.text: Where is chromosomal DNA found in bacteria?

explanation.concept_text: Recall that prokaryotes are made up of the domains Bacteria and Archaea. Most bacteria contain their DNA in only one circular, double-stranded chromosome, located in a region of the cell called a nucleoid – an irregularly shaped region inside all prokaryotic cells. Therefore, Option D , Nucleoid , is the correct answer. The nucleoid is not to be confused with the nucleus; all prokaryotes, including bacteria, lack a nucleus. Genetic information can also be present in the form of a plasmid , which is a small circular double-stranded DNA molecule. However, it is important to note that plasmids DO NOT contain the bacterium’s own chromosomal DNA. Plasmids are independent genetic molecules that can be transmitted from one bacterium to another; they are not part of the bacterium’s chromosome. Plasmids can carry genetic information for traits such as antibiotic resistance, which can be spread from one bacterium to another. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Nucleus – This option is incorrect because bacteria are prokaryotic cells and therefore DO NOT contain membrane-bound organelles such as a nucleus. In prokaryotic cells, the chromosomal DNA is tightly condensed in the nucleoid region, which is not enclosed by any membrane. In eukaryotic cells, the nucleus functions as the cell’s control center for gene expression, protein synthesis, and cell division. Option B. Capsule – This option is incorrect because the capsule is the outer envelope of some bacterial cells and is made of polysaccharides. It functions to protect the bacterium from being phagocytosed; therefore, a bacterium with capsules tends to be more virulent. Since the capsule is the outer envelope of the entire bacterium this option cannot be correct. Option C. Plasmid – This option might be tempting if you do not read the question carefully. Indeed, a plasmid is a piece of DNA found inside bacteria. However, the question is specifically asking about chromosomal DNA (i.e., the bacterium’s own DNA which codes for its own structure and function). Plasmids are NOT part of the chromosomal DNA of a bacterium. Plasmids are independent circular DNA molecules found physically separate from the bacterium’s chromosomal DNA and can be shared between bacteria via conjugation. Recall that transduction and transformation are two additional ways for prokaryotes to share DNA with each other. However, out of the three methods, only conjugation involves plasmids. Option E. Flagella – This option is incorrect because flagella are not involved in the storage of DNA. Instead, flagella are whip-like structures that contribute to the locomotion of the cell. They are found in bacteria, archaea, and even some eukaryotes.

question.text: Which of the following strongly supports the endosymbiotic theory regarding the origins of mitochondria and chloroplasts?

explanation.concept_text: Eukaryotic cells may have evolved when multiple cells joined together into one and began to live in symbiotic relationships. The theory that explains how this could have happened is called endosymbiotic theory. An endosymbiont is one organism that lives inside of another one. The mitochondrion and the chloroplast are both organelles that were once free-living prokaryotic cells that were endocytosed by other cells known as host cells. Rather than being digested by or killing the host cell, the inner cell survived, and they thrived together. The host cell provides a comfortable, safe place to live, and the organelle makes energy that the host cell can use. This happened a long time ago, and over time the organelle and host cell evolved together. Now one cannot exist without the other as they function as a single organism. The main evidence for this theory is the prokaryotic properties of mitochondria and chloroplasts. Mitochondria and chloroplasts are surrounded by double-membrane envelopes, the inner one (according to endosymbiotic theory) derived from the cell membrane of the small prokaryote that got endocytosed, just like a prokaryotic cell does. The endosymbiotic theory also explains why mitochondria and chloroplasts have a double membrane . As illustrated in the image below, during endocytosis, the endosymbiont retains its original cell membrane in addition to being engulfed by the cell membrane of the host cell, resulting in a double membrane. Mitochondria and chloroplasts also have their own circular DNA genome, just like a bacteria’s genome. This DNA is passed from a mitochondrion to its offspring and is separate from the host cell’s genome in the nucleus. Mitochondria resemble tiny bacteria. The endosymbiotic event that generated mitochondria happened early in the history of eukaryotes as all eukaryotes have them. Later on, a similar event brought chloroplasts into some eukaryotic cells, creating the lineage that led to plants. Therefore, the correct answer is Option A. Both contain circular DNA . CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Both have a single membrane – This option is incorrect because both have a double membrane which means that they may have been engulfed by other cells through endocytosis. During endocytosis, their original cell membrane is retained and is engulfed by the new cell membrane of the host cell. As a result, mitochondria and chloroplast now have two membranes instead of one. Moreover, both mitochondria and chloroplasts will be unable to function without a double membrane since it plays a vital role in their function. Recall that the proton gradient and electron transport chain of mitochondria and chloroplasts cannot function without the presence of two membranes. Option C. Both contain single-stranded DNA – This option is incorrect because both have double-stranded DNA. Recall that single-stranded DNA is a lot less stable and thus more susceptible to damage over time. If mitochondria and chloroplasts had single-stranded DNA, they likely would not have survived the billions of years of evolution so far. Single-stranded DNA is mostly found in viruses such as retroviruses and bacteriophages (viruses that infect bacteria). Living organisms always have DNA in the double-stranded form. Option D. Both have histone proteins – The DNA of eukaryotic cells wraps around histone proteins to form chromatin, a condensed version of DNA. This option is incorrect because neither mitochondrial nor chloroplast DNA wraps around histone proteins. The absence of histone proteins in mitochondrial and chloroplast DNA further supports the endosymbiotic theory. This is because histone proteins are NOT found in prokaryotic DNA -- they are found only in eukaryotic DNA. Option E. Both have 80S ribosomes – This option is incorrect because both have 70S ribosomes, the same as prokaryotic cells. Recall that a larger S value (Svedberg value) indicates a heavier molecule. The ribosomal characteristics of mitochondria and chloroplasts are another indicator in favor of the endosymbiotic theory. Although eukaryotic ribosomes are 80S, their mitochondria and chloroplasts have 70S ribosomes, much like prokaryotes.

question.text: Which of the following is the most superficial layer of the epidermis?

explanation.concept_text: The skin can be divided into three main layers. From most superficial to least, the order is epidermis , dermis , and hypodermis (subcutaneous tissue). Within the most superficial layer of the skin, the epidermis, there are 5 distinct layers . The most superficial layer of the epidermis is called the stratum corneum . It consists of 25-30 layers of dead cells. It consists of keratin, lipids, and lamellar granules which makes it water-repellant. A mnemonic to help you remember the layers of the skin from most superficial to deepest: C ome L et’s G et S un B urnt, corresponding to the stratum C orneum, L ucidum, G ranulosum, S pinosum, and B asale. Be careful and recall that the deepest layer of the epidermis, basale, is also commonly referred to as germinativum. Do not fall for the common mistake of confusing the two layers that start with the letter G (granulosum vs germinativum). In the mnemonic, the ‘G’ refers to the ‘stratum granulosum’ while the ‘B’ refers to the deepest layer, ‘stratum basale’ also known as the ‘stratum germinativum.’ Make sure you memorize both names of the deepest layer because they can be used interchangeably in the test. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Stratum spinosum – This option is incorrect because the stratum spinosum is deeper than the stratum corneum. The stratum spinosum contributes to the overall strength and flexibility of the epidermis. This is achieved through its high number of desmosome junctions holding together its keratinocytes. This high prevalence of desmosome junctions also gives this layer a “spiny” appearance, hence the name spinosum. The stratum spinosum is also critical in the skin's immune response because this layer holds the highest number of Langerhans cells. Option C. Stratum granulosum – This option is incorrect because it is the next layer deeper than the stratum lucidum layer. The stratum granulosum is composed of 3-5 layers of dying keratinocytes that have migrated from the stratum spinosum. The keratinocytes in this layer release hydrophobic lipids which contribute to the skin’s water barrier. These hydrophobic lipids are also known as lamellar granules, hence the name granulosum. Option D. Stratum lucidum – This option is incorrect because it is the next layer deeper than the stratum corneum layer. An important detail regarding the stratum lucidum is that this layer is present only in the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. As a result, these areas have an increased thickness of the skin and thus more protection against damage and water loss. A useful mnemonic is to remember that the letter L (for Lucidum) looks like the foot of a stick figure, thus Lucidum is the layer present in hands and feet! Option E. Stratum germinativum – This option is incorrect because this is the deepest layer of the epidermis. It is important to remember that the stratum germinativum is also known as the stratum basale and should not be confused with the stratum granulosum. Since this is the deepest layer of the epidermis, this is where keratinocyte stem cells divide to produce keratinocytes that are gradually pushed up to the most superficial layer of the epidermis. The stratum germinativum also houses melanocytes, responsible for skin pigmentation and protection from UV radiation, as well as Merkel cells, responsible for the sensation of light touch.

question.text: Which of the following proteins are most likely to be found in the extracellular matrix?

explanation.concept_text: The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a mesh of various proteins and carbohydrates that, as the name suggests, are located outside of cells (extra- meaning “outside”). More specifically the ECM occupies the space between adjacent animal cells. Its two main purposes are to provide mechanical support as cells hold onto and support each other as well as to aid in cell signaling between cells. The main component of the ECM is the protein collagen . Therefore, Option B , Collagen , is the correct answer. In fact, collagen is the most abundant protein not just in the ECM, but the entire body. It is produced by fibroblast cells and gives structural integrity to tissues in the body. The ECM can connect to the cell membrane thanks to the protein’s integrin, laminin, and fibronectin. Recall that integrins are considered transmembrane proteins because they span the entire double membrane of the cell, connecting the ECM to the inside of the cell. Integrins act as a communication channel for signals across the cell membrane while also providing structural integrity. Laminin and fibronectin, on the other hand, serve as adhesion points for the ECM to hold onto the integrin proteins. On the opposing end of integrin proteins (inside the cell) these transmembrane proteins attach to the cell's cytoskeleton. The image below demonstrates the structure of the extracellular matrix and how it interacts with cellular structures. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Keratin – This option is incorrect because keratin is a protein involved in maintaining cell shape as an intermediate filament inside of the cell. This option may be tempting, however, keratin is NOT part of the extracellular matrix. Instead, keratin is what attaches the extracellular matrix to the cell in hemidesmosome junctions. Option C. Tubulin – This option is incorrect because tubulin is a protein that is involved in the formation of the eukaryotic cytoskeleton inside the cell, not in the extracellular matrix. If enough tubulin molecules are assorted together, they make up a microtubule. Recall that microtubules are vital in the cell because of their role in cell structure, locomotion, and division—no cell would be able to divide without a microtubule organizing center (MTOCs) to form a spindle apparatus. Option D. Actin – This option is incorrect because this is a protein that has many functions inside cells such as motility and shape maintenance inside of the cell, not outside .  This option may have been tempting; however, actin is NOT located in the extracellular matrix. Instead, keratin is what attaches the extracellular matrix to the cell in focal adhesion junctions. Option E. Centrioles – This option is incorrect because these act inside cells to form spindle fibers during cell division. Also, though they are mainly made of proteins like tubulin, they are themselves an organelle and are not located in the extracellular matrix.

question.text: A man with type A+ blood had children with a woman with type AB- blood. All of the following are possible blood types they could have EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Erythrocytes (red blood cells) are responsible for carrying oxygen to body tissues to be used for ATP production. Erythrocytes have a double concave shape which allows for an increased rate of gas exchange because of the increased surface area but also allows various antigens to attach to the surface. Individuals with type A blood have only antigen A on their erythrocytes, individuals with type B blood have only antigen B, individuals with type AB blood have both antigens, whereas type O blood has neither A nor B antigens. The Rhesus factor (Rh) is another important antigen that attaches to the red blood cells of some but not all individuals. A person whose red blood cells carry the Rh factor is said to be Rh positive (+), otherwise, a person who lacks the antigen is said to be Rh negative (-). As shown in the image below, every person’s immune system produces antibodies against non-self-antigens. Our immune system does NOT produce antibodies against its own type of antigen, otherwise our body would be constantly attacking its own red blood cells. CC BY 4.0 For questions regarding blood type, recall that the O allele is recessive , whereas A and B alleles are dominant . Therefore, it has become convention when discussing phenotypes to omit the O allele if it is being dominated by another allele. Moreover, if the genotype is composed of the same two alleles—for example, BB— the phenotype can be expressed as just “type B.” In this question, the man’s phenotype is A + , therefore, his genotype must be either AO + or AA + . The woman’s genotype is AB – . By creating a Punnet square, we can determine the possibilities of different offspring with type A, B, or AB blood. Since the allele O is recessive, the only way for an individual to have a phenotype O is to have the genotype OO. Using the Punnet square we can see that an offspring between these two individuals cannot have blood type O. Therefore, Option E. O + is correct .
explanation.poe_text: Option A. A – – This option is incorrect because when an A + individual and an AB – individual have a child, there is a 50% chance of type A blood, 25% chance of type B blood, and a 25% chance of type AB blood. Also, both positive and negative blood types can be possible since the A + individual may be heterozygote (Rh + /Rh – ). Since we want to choose an option that is not a possibility for a child, this answer is incorrect. Option B. B + – This option is incorrect because when an A + individual and an AB – individual have a child, there is a 50% chance of type A blood, 25% chance of type B blood, and a 25% chance of type AB blood. Also, both positive and negative blood types can be possible since the A + individual may be heterozygote (Rh + /Rh – ). Since we want to choose an option that is not a possibility for a child, this answer is incorrect. Option C. AB – – This option is incorrect because when an A + individual and an AB – individual have a child, there is a 50% chance of type A blood, 25% chance of type B blood, and a 25% chance of type AB blood. Also, both positive and negative blood types can be possible since the A + individual may be heterozygote (Rh + /Rh – ). Since we want to choose an option that is not a possibility for a child, this answer is incorrect. Option D. B – – This option is incorrect because when an A + individual and an AB – individual have a child, there is a 50% chance of type A blood, 25% chance of type B blood, and a 25% chance of type AB blood. Also, both positive and negative blood types can be possible since the A + individual may be heterozygote (Rh + /Rh – ). Since we want to choose an option that is not a possibility for a child, this answer is incorrect.

question.text: Secondary messengers are important in cell signaling pathways and can greatly amplify the strength of the signal. All of the following are secondary messengers EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Secondary messengers are molecules that relay signals received at receptors on the cell surface to target molecules in the cytosol and/or nucleus. In addition to their job as relay molecules, secondary messengers greatly amplify the signal's strength. The binding of a ligand to a single receptor at the cell surface may end up causing massive changes in the biochemical activities within the cell, such as gene expression, metabolism, and cell division. A malfunction of secondary messenger signaling in the body may lead to numerous diseases. Some examples include the loss of function of a particular cell or the gain of function, leading to uncontrolled cell growth. There are 3 major classes of secondary messengers to know for the test:
explanation.poe_text: Option A. cAMP – This option is incorrect because cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) is a secondary messenger and can activate an enzyme called “Protein Kinase A” (PKA), enabling it to phosphorylate its targets and pass along the signal. Protein kinase A is found in a variety of types of cells, and it has different target proteins in each. This allows the same cAMP secondary messenger to produce different responses in different contexts. Option B. IP3 – This option is incorrect because IP3 (inositol triphosphate) is a secondary messenger. It diffuses into the cytoplasm and can bind to ligand-gated calcium channels in the endoplasmic reticulum, releasing Ca 2+ ions into the cytosol that continue the signal cascade. Option C. Calcium – This option is incorrect because Ca 2+ (calcium ions) are a widely used type of secondary messenger. In pathways that use calcium ions as a secondary messenger, upstream signaling events release a ligand that binds to and opens ligand-gated calcium ion channels. These channels open and allow the higher levels of Ca 2+ that are present outside the cell (or in intracellular storage compartments) to flow into the cytoplasm, raising the concentration of cytoplasmic Ca 2+ . Option E. DAG – This option is incorrect because DAG (diacylglycerol) is a secondary messenger. It stays in the plasma membrane and can activate a target called protein kinase C (PKC), allowing it to phosphorylate its own targets.

question.text: The thoracic cavity contains all of the following EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: The thoracic cavity is the second largest hollow space of the body. It is also called the “chest cavity” and is enclosed by the ribs, the vertebral column, and the sternum (or breastbone). The cavity is lined by a two-layered membrane; the visceral pleura lines the surface of the lungs, and the parietal pleura lines the inside of the chest cavity, leaving the in-between space known as the intrapleural space . The thoracic cavity sits above the abdominal cavity (the body’s largest hollow space) and the two are separated by the diaphragm, a large, dome-shaped muscle as shown in the image below. The diaphragm is sometimes thought of as just the lower border of the chest cavity and its significance is overlooked. It is important to remember that it would be impossible for our lungs to inhale and exhale air without the proper function of the diaphragm. Due to the diaphragm’s shape, once it contracts, it flattens out and increases the volume of the chest cavity. As a result, negative pressure is created and air rushes in the lungs. The structures within the thoracic cavity include organs like the heart, lungs, trachea, esophagus, endocrine glands, and the thymus. Since the stomach is not part of the thoracic cavity, Option E , Stomach , is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Lungs – This option is incorrect because the lungs are located within the thoracic cavity as shown in the image above. One of the thoracic cavity's major functions is to safely hold major organs like the lungs. The lungs are a pair of organs whose primary function is to facilitate the disposal of carbon dioxide byproducts from cellular respiration as well as the oxygenation of blood before it is sent to tissues and organs all over the body. The site of gas exchange in the lungs is the alveoli – very small air sacs that are wrapped in capillaries (very thin blood vessels). Option B. Heart – This option is incorrect because the heart is located within the thoracic cavity, as shown in the image above. One of the thoracic cavity's major functions is to safely hold major organs like the heart. The heart is the main organ of the circulatory system and functions to deliver oxygen-rich blood to organs and tissues in need, while also removing excess waste and byproducts such as carbon dioxide. The heart is divided into four chambers: two upper chambers called the atria, and two lower chambers called the ventricles. Using the depolarization signals of the sinoatrial (SA) node as a pacemaker, the four chambers work together to pump deoxygenated blood to the lungs and oxygenated blood to the rest of the body. Option C. Esophagus – This option is incorrect because the esophagus is located within the thoracic cavity, as shown in the image above. The esophagus is a muscular tube connecting the throat to the stomach. Using the upper and lower esophageal sphincters and peristalsis motion, chewed food (bolus) is guided to the stomach while preventing the reflux of gastric contents. Option D. Thymus gland – This option is incorrect because the thymus gland is located within the thoracic cavity, as shown in the image above. Located in the upper chest, the thymus gland is a crucial organ of the immune system. Its primary function is the maturation of T cells, which play a vital role in the body's adaptive immune response. Remember that the thymus is not involved in T cell production , rather, just the T cell maturation.

question.text: The improper use of antibiotics can result in __________.

explanation.concept_text: Antibiotics are medicines designed to kill bacteria and/or stop their growth. They do this by interfering with vital cell structures (e.g. cell wall) or cell processes (e.g. DNA replication or protein synthesis). Despite their life-saving use in medicine, antibiotics come with certain risks. The misuse of antibiotics (primarily their overuse) may lead to serious complications. For example, certain antibiotics reduce Vitamin K absorption in the body by killing off the "good" bacteria in your digestive system responsible for facilitating vitamin synthesis or absorption. As such, improper use of antibiotics can lead to a vitamin deficiency in the body, which makes Option C the correct answer. Antibiotic resistance is another risk of antibiotic use that may appear on your test. Antibiotic resistance occurs when bacteria evolve and can survive exposure to antibiotics that were once effective in killing them. This process is accelerated by the overuse of antibiotics. When antibiotics are used unnecessarily, such as for viral infections (against which they are ineffective), or when courses of antibiotics are not completed, it creates additional selective pressure that favors the survival and spread of resistant bacteria. This can lead to persistent infections, posing a significant threat to public health. The image below shows how antibiotic resistance happens. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Sunburn – This option is incorrect because sunburn is not caused by the use of antibiotics. Instead, sunburn is caused when too much ultraviolet (UV) light from the sun hits the skin. Because of the UV radiation, DNA damage occurs in keratinocytes, which then illicit an immune response and result in the redness and swelling commonly associated with sunburns. Option B. Hair loss – This option is incorrect because the use of antibiotics does not impact hair loss since it is not a symptom of a lack of vitamin K. Some medications that can indeed cause hair loss are blood thinners, chemotherapy drugs, and certain antidepressants. Option D. Blindness – This option is incorrect because although antibiotics may cause visual disturbances, they will not cause complete blindness. Some factors that can indeed cause hair loss are untreated diabetes and smoking. Option E. Muscle Hypertrophy – This option is incorrect because antibiotics do not have any direct impact on muscle growth; their main purpose is to kill and/or stop the growth of bacteria. They achieve this by interfering with vital cell structures (e.g. cell wall) or cell processes (e.g. DNA replication or protein synthesis). On the other hand, muscle growth is primarily influenced by factors such as exercise, nutrition, and certain hormones such as testosterone. It's important to distinguish between antibiotics and anabolic steroids, which are synthetic hormones that can directly promote muscle growth.

question.text: A skunk screeches to alert its fellow population of a predator nearby. What is the benefit of this behavior?

options.label: C.
options.text: Scares the predator due to mimicry

explanation.concept_text: Many of the behaviors observed in animals can be attributed to evolution and natural selection. Remember that these processes do not only select for the ability to survive but just as importantly, they select for the ability to pass down one’s genes. Interestingly, some animals have evolved behaviors that decrease the individual’s survival to increase their relatives’ survival. In this question, a skunk’s act of screeching to alert of a nearby predator is decreasing its own chances of survival by making itself more obvious to the predator. Why would evolution select for a behavior that decreases the individual’s fitness? Because the nearby skunks who benefit from this behavior (relatives) are highly likely to share identical genes and will therefore pass down many of the screeching skunk's genes. Remember that natural selection favors genetic success, not necessarily reproductive success. This unselfish behavior is a type of altruistic behavior, and it increases the inclusive fitness of the population. Inclusive fitness is the sum of an animal’s direct and indirect fitness. Direct fitness refers to the genes an individual can pass on to the next generation on its own, while indirect fitness refers to the genes that are passed on through the individual’s relatives. Therefore, Option E , Increases inclusive fitness , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Decreases rate of mutations – This option is incorrect because the skunk’s screech would not affect the rate of mutations. Recall that mutations are permanent changes in an organism’s DNA sequence, and they occur either randomly or due to exposure to mutagens such as certain chemicals, infectious agents, or radiation. Option B. Utilizes camouflage effectively – This option is incorrect because camouflage is a defense mechanism meant to disguise the animal and decrease the chances of it being spotted by a predator. In this example, the skunk’s screech has the opposite effect. By screeching, the skunk brings the predator’s attention to itself. Moreover, not only do skunks NOT use camouflage, but they also exhibit aposematic coloration, which is a bold and distinctive coloration on their fur to visually stand out and warn predators to stay away. Option C. Scares the predator due to mimicry – This option is incorrect because mimicry occurs when two or more distinct species evolve to resemble each other in physical appearance, and this is not the case in this example. When a skunk screeches, it is not mimicking another species. Rather, it is communicating to its relatives that there is a potentially dangerous predator nearby. Option D. Boosts immune system activity – This option is incorrect because there is no direct causal link between a skunk screeching and a boost in its immune system. It should be noted that there is a link between acute stress (such as fight or flight response) affecting the activity of certain immune cells, however, this change in immune activity is caused by stress hormones (e.g., cortisol and epinephrine), NOT the screeching, as the answer choice suggests.

question.text: During embryologic development, the stage that is best described as a hollow sphere of cells is called a __________.

explanation.concept_text: The blastula is a key stage during embryological development where a hollow sphere of cells is formed. First, fertilization of the egg by the sperm usually takes place in the oviduct (aka fallopian tube). As the zygote travels through the oviduct toward the uterus, the cleavage process takes place. During this process, the zygote undergoes cell division without increasing in overall size. In other words, the total mass and total volume occupied by the sum of cells remain constant as the cells within the zona pellucida are further subdividing. Each new cell formed is termed a blastomere and each daughter cell is smaller (less cytoplasm) than its mother cell. Once the solid ball of cells reaches a quantity of 16-32, it is termed a morula. After that, the liquid starts to fill within the morula, pushing the middle cells outward as they continuously divide, creating a blastocoel (empty cavity) within the middle. The blastocoel cavity continues to grow outward and once complete, it forms a blastula , a hollow sphere of cells. Therefore, Option B , Blastula , is the correct answer. Blastula cells are pluripotent, meaning they can develop into any type of cell EXCEPT an entire organism. On the other hand, morula cells are totipotent because they CAN develop into an entire organism in addition to any cell type. The cleavage process ends once the blastula is formed. The image below provides a visualization of the process of cleavage. Note that in mammals, the blastula is called the blastocyst. The distinguishing feature of blastocysts is that they contain the inner cell mass (ICM), whereas blastula does not. The ICM is a mass of pluripotent cells located inside the blastocyst and eventually gives rise to the epiblast and hypoblast. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Gastrula – This option is incorrect because the gastrula is formed after the hollow sphere of cells (blastula). Gastrulation is the formation of a trilaminar (three-layered) embryo. By late gastrulation, the trilaminar disc is composed of the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm layers. Each of these layers will go on to form distinct organs in the embryo. Option C. Morula – This option is incorrect because the morula precedes the blastula in the cleavage process, and it is simply a solid ball of cells lacking the hollow cavity known as the blastocoel. The blastocoel begins forming when the morula is made up of approximately 128 cells. Option D. Blastomere – This option is incorrect because blastomeres are the newly formed cells of the cleavage process. That is, each new cell being produced is called a blastomere. Until the morula is formed, all blastomeres being produced are identical totipotent stem cells. Totipotent cells can give rise to any and all types of human cells, and even an entire functional organism. In contrast, the blastomeres being produced after the morula stage (during the blastula stage) are pluripotent cells, which can give rise to any tissue type, but not an entire functional organism. Option E. Blastopore – This option is incorrect because the blastopore is an invagination within the gastrula that can later in development become either the mouth or the anus, depending on the type of organism. In protostomes, the blastopore becomes the mouth, and in deuterostomes, it becomes the anus. The blastopore is a crucial structure in the development of the three germ layers – ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The outermost layer, ectoderm, gives rise to skin, hair, enamel of teeth, nails, and the nervous system. The middle layer, mesoderm, gives rise to muscles, bones, heart, blood, kidneys, and reproductive organs. Lastly, the innermost layer, the endoderm, gives rise to the lining of the digestive tract, the lymphatic system, the pancreas, the liver, the thymus, the thyroid, and the parathyroid.

question.text: Which of the following smells like rotten eggs and is produced under anaerobic conditions in swamps and sewers?

explanation.concept_text: The key to answering this question is to look for the answer choice that contains sulfur because it is known to smell like rotten eggs . Therefore, Option D , H 2 S , which contains the only compound with sulfur, is the correct answer. If you’ve ever gotten a hair perm, you must have noticed the distinctive rotten egg odor it leaves. This is caused by the denaturation of the sulfur-containing disulfide bonds found in hair. Even some car owners report their exhaust smelling like rotten eggs, which is caused by a faulty exhaust system that does not process fuel correctly and leaves higher concentrations of sulfur as a byproduct. Hydrogen sulfide (H 2 S) is produced by the metabolism of organic material in anaerobic conditions (absence of oxygen). In anaerobic conditions, sulfur rather than oxygen can be reduced to H 2 S. Such microbes reside in swamps, marshes, bogs, and sewers. Another byproduct of metabolism in these microbes is methane (CH 4 ), and carbon dioxide (CO 2 ), which together constitute “swamp gas”.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. CO 2 – This option is incorrect because carbon dioxide gas is odorless. Moreover, it does not contain any sulfur, which is known to have a smell similar to rotten eggs. Our most common exposure to CO 2 is as a byproduct of respiration and combustion. Option B. CH 4 – This option is incorrect because methane gas does not contain any sulfur, (which causes a smell like rotten eggs). Instead, methane’s odor is commonly associated with swamps and landfills because it is produced by decomposing organic matter. The human digestive system also produces methane as a byproduct of digestion; however, it does not give off an odor similar to rotten eggs. Option C. NH 3 – This option is incorrect because ammonia gas does not contain any sulfur (which causes a smell like rotten eggs). Instead, the odor of ammonia gas is often compared to that of urine. This is because urea, one of the main waste products found in urine, can further break down into ammonia. Option E. HCN – This option is incorrect because hydrogen cyanide gas does not contain any sulfur (which causes a smell like rotten eggs). Hydrogen cyanide gas is flammable and extremely poisonous. It has an odor similar to almonds.

question.text: Which of the following organs is correctly matched with its embryonic germ layer of origin?

options.label: E.
options.text: Cardiac Muscle and reproductive tract – Endoderm

explanation.concept_text: Triploblastic organisms have three germ layers: the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The three germ layers are formed during early embryonic development and give rise to all the organs and tissue of the eventual organism. When trying to match a tissue or organ to its germ layer, it might be helpful to simplify the concept and memorize the exceptions. For example, a simplified way of tackling this question would be to recognize that the innermost layer ( endoderm) gives rise to the inner lining of the gastrointestinal and respiratory cavities, plus some exceptions included such as the liver, pancreas, thyroid, and parathyroid gland. On the other end of the spectrum, the outermost layer ( ectoderm ) gives rise to anything visible from the outside like the epidermis – or anything that has direct interaction with the outside like the nervous system. Lastly, everything else can be considered part of the middle layer ( mesoderm) . Remember that this should only be used as a general guide and should not substitute memorizing the germ layer derivatives. Now, to go into more specific detail, the ectoderm is the outermost germ layer in the developing embryo and develops into the nervous system (spine, peripheral nerves, and brain), tooth enamel, epidermis, hair, and nails. Regarding the eye, the ectoderm contributes to the formation of the lens, eyelid, and corneal epithelium. Therefore, Option B , Eyes, and epidermis – Ectoderm , is the correct answer. The mesoderm is the middle of three germ layers, and it gives rise to muscles, bones, the heart, blood, kidneys, the lymphatic system, and the reproductive organs. The endoderm is the innermost layer and gives rise to the epithelial lining of the digestive and respiratory tract, parts of the liver, pancreas, gall bladder, thyroid & parathyroid, thymus, and urinary bladder lining. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Lungs and cilia – Ectoderm – This option is incorrect because the lungs arise from the endoderm. Also, the cilia do not arise from any germ layer and are considered a cellular structure, not an organ. Cilia are used by cells for locomotion through space or to move waste and debris past a cell (e.g., cilia located along the airway tract move debris out of the airway). The lungs are the main organ of the respiratory system, and they facilitate the exchange of carbon dioxide from the blood with oxygen from the atmosphere through breathing. Option C. Neurons and Muscle – Mesoderm – This option is incorrect because neurons are derived from the ectoderm layer. Even though muscles arise from the mesoderm and are therefore matched correctly, the neurons part of this answer choice does not match correctly, which makes option C incorrect. Neurons are the basic functional unit of the nervous system, and they transmit electrical signals known as action potentials to facilitate functions as basic as breathing and moving to as complex as thinking and playing a musical instrument. Option D. Liver and Spleen – Ectoderm – This option is incorrect because the liver is derived from the endoderm layer and the spleen is derived from the mesoderm layer. The liver is located between the diaphragm and the stomach. The liver's main functions are the production of bile and the filtration and detoxification of blood. The spleen is part of the lymphatic system and functions to control the level of leukocytes (white blood cells) in the blood while also removing old or damaged red blood cells. Option E. Cardiac Muscle and reproductive tract – Endoderm – This option is incorrect because cardiac muscle is derived from the mesoderm layer. In fact, all three types of muscle in the body – skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscle – are derived from the mesoderm. Unlike skeletal and smooth muscle, the contraction of cardiac muscle does not need stimulation from external nerves, instead, it is controlled by the depolarization signals coming from the SA (sinoatrial) node.

question.text: Which of the following types of cells resorb bone matrix?

explanation.concept_text: Bone matrix is made up of various substances, including calcium, collagen, and water. Bone is continually created, broken down, and remodeled. Components of the matrix are produced by cells known as osteoblasts. In other words, osteoblasts are responsible for the process of laying down new bone material in a process known as ossification. Osteocyte cells play a maintenance role and can also build bone. Osteoclast cells are involved in the resorption of bone by releasing acid and enzymes to break down components of the matrix, then engulfing and digesting fragments. Therefore, Option B , Osteoclasts , is the correct answer. The process of bone remodeling constantly switches between ossification and resorption based on the needs of the body such as bone growth, bone repair, and regulating blood calcium levels. Bone remodeling is mainly regulated by vitamin D, calcitonin, and parathyroid hormone (PTH). Vitamin D achieves this by stimulating osteoblast activity while also helping the body absorb calcium from the intestines. Calcitonin is produced by the thyroid gland and functions to inhibit osteoclast activity. In other words, calcitonin slows down bone resorption and indirectly promotes bone formation. On the other hand, parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates osteoclast activity which induces bone resorption. One can see the importance of healthy hormone levels in the body, in addition to the healthy function of the glands secreting said hormones. Individuals with abnormal thyroid or parathyroid glands experience problematic bone remodeling as one of their symptoms. Matrix cells have a common naming convention. Cells ending in “-blast” build matrix (blast = build), cells ending in “-cyte” are involved in maintenance, and cells ending in “-clast” are involved in the breakdown. For example, chondroblasts produce the matrix of cartilage. The image below illustrates the roles of these cells in the bone remodeling process. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Osteoblasts – This option is incorrect because osteoblasts are not responsible for resorbing bone matrix. In fact, osteoblasts accomplish the opposite of bone resorption; osteoblasts build bone. They accomplish this by secreting bone matrix containing the collagen, proteins, and minerals used to make bone. One helpful mnemonic is the osteo B lasts B uild bone. At a certain point, osteoblasts get enveloped by the surrounding bone matrix they have secreted, and they differentiate to become osteocytes. Option C. Osteocytes – This option is incorrect because these are cells that maintain the bone matrix and therefore are not responsible for resorbing bone matrix. Moreover, osteocytes are the matured version of osteoblasts. They are incapable of mitosis and use blood for the exchange of nutrients and waste products, helping to maintain the bone. Osteocytes have good access to blood vessels because they are in the osteon's lacunae (functional unit of compact bone). There, osteocytes surround the Haversian canals of bone, which contain blood vessels, nerves, and lymphatic vessels. Option D. Osteons – This option is incorrect because this is the functional unit of compact bone. These are roughly cylindrical structures consisting of a central Haversian canal containing a blood supply and concentric layers called lamellae. The lamellae are made of collagen fibers and mineralized bone matrix. Because of this, osteons provide strength and resistance to forces such as compression, bending, and twisting. Moreover, the osteon is crucial in the exchange of blood and nutrients to the bone because it shapes the Haversian canal, which houses blood vessels, lymphatic vessels, and nerves. Option E. Chondroblasts – This option is incorrect because these are cells that produce the matrix of cartilage and therefore are not responsible for resorbing bone matrix. Chondroblasts are part of connective tissue, not bone. However, chondroblasts are crucial in the smooth and healthy connection and function of different bones with each other. Chondroblasts secrete cartilaginous matrix which gives cartilage its strength and elasticity because of the collagen and elastin it is made from. Like osteoblasts, chondroblasts eventually get enveloped by the surrounding matrix they’ve secreted, and they differentiate to become chondrocytes. Unlike osteoblasts, however, chondroblasts do not have a good blood supply and, as a result, cannot repair cartilage as quickly as bone.

question.text: An experiment on a nerve cell comes to an abrupt end due to an accidental mutation that disables the cell’s Na + /K + pump. Which of the following would result from the lack of Na + /K + pump function?

options.label: B.
options.text: Sodium will continue to diffuse out of the cell

options.label: E.
options.text: Potassium will continue to diffuse into the cell

explanation.concept_text: The Na⁺/K⁺ pump plays a crucial role in maintaining the correct ion balance at the resting membrane potential of a cell. At rest, sodium ions exist in high concentration outside the cell, while potassium levels are high inside of the cell. During a normal action potential, voltage-gated sodium channels open, allowing Na⁺ ions to flow into the cell. This causes the membrane potential to become more positive and results in a high sodium concentration inside the cell. During the repolarization that follows to return the membrane potential to a resting state, voltage-gated potassium channels open, causing potassium ions to rush out of the cell. At this point, the cell has restored its membrane potential but has an ion imbalance: sodium needs to be brought back outside the cell, and potassium needs to be brought back inside. This requires the use of the Na⁺/K⁺ pump. The pump uses ATP to actively transport 3 Na⁺ ions out of the cell and bring 2 K⁺ ions into the cell, which restores the normal ion balance. The pump requires ATP for energy to drive the exchange of ions, so if it cannot respond to ATP, it cannot function and will no longer transport Na⁺ out of the cell, leading to less sodium in the extracellular space (as sodium would instead be trapped inside the cell after a depolarization). Therefore, Option A. Less sodium outside the cell is the correct answer. One fun mnemonic for the ratio of ions being exchanged is “321 NOKIA”: 3 N a + O utside 2 K + I nside 1 A tp used CC BY 3.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Sodium will continue to diffuse out of the cell – This option is incorrect because the role of the sodium-potassium pump is to pump 3 sodium ions outside of the cell while also pumping 2 potassium ions inside the cell. Without a properly functioning sodium potassium pump, sodium cannot diffuse out of the cell. Option C. Potassium levels will fall extracellularly – This option is incorrect because the role of the sodium-potassium pump is to pump 3 sodium ions outside of the cell while also pumping 2 potassium ions inside the cell. Without a properly functioning sodium potassium pump, potassium ions cannot move from the outside of the cell to the inside. Therefore, potassium ions will be stuck outside of the cell, and this will cause an increase in extracellular potassium levels. Option D. Sodium levels increase extracellularly – This option is incorrect because the role of the sodium-potassium pump is to pump 3 sodium ions outside of the cell while also pumping 2 potassium ions inside the cell. Without a properly functioning sodium potassium pump, sodium ions will not be able to move from the inside of the cell to the outside. Therefore, sodium ions will be stuck inside the cell, and this will cause a fall in the extracellular sodium levels. Option E. Potassium will continue to diffuse into the cell – This option is incorrect because the role of the sodium-potassium pump is to pump 3 sodium ions outside of the cell while also pumping 2 potassium ions inside the cell. Without a properly functioning sodium potassium pump, potassium cannot diffuse into the cell.

question.text: Which of the following is most analogous to chlorophyll in chloroplasts?

explanation.concept_text: Solving this problem requires recognizing that both heme and chlorophyll are pigments with a metal atom coordinated in their center, as shown in the image below. They both have color because of an extended conjugated system. This conjugated system refers to the alternating single and double bonds in both molecules. In fact, both heme and chlorophyll are porphyrins , a class of conjugated systems with a large cyclic structure. Therefore, Option D . Heme in hemoglobin is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Albumin in serum – This option is incorrect because albumin is a water-soluble protein that transports water-insoluble fatty acids. It is not a pigment like chlorophyll, nor does it have a coordinated metal atom in its center. Albumin is produced by the liver, and it is the most abundant protein found in the blood. It can function as a protein carrier while also regulating many aspects of the body such as blood pressure, blood pH levels, and inflammation. Option B. Interleukin in leukocytes – This option is incorrect because interleukins are cytokines produced by activated helper T cells to stimulate other lymphocytes in response to detected pathogens. Interleukins are not pigments and do not share any structural similarities with heme and chlorophyll. While leukocytes are called white blood cells, they are, in fact, colorless (appear white under light microscopy). Option C. Bilirubin in hepatocytes – This option is incorrect because bilirubin is a yellow compound resulting from the breakdown of heme. Its structure resembles a cyclic heme molecule that was cut on one part of the loop and has lost the coordinate metal atom. As a result, bilirubin cannot be considered analogous to the structure of chlorophyll in chloroplasts as it lacks the central metal atom.

question.text: The following statements are true regarding the left ventricle EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: The wall of the left ventricle is the thickest of the heart

options.label: B.
options.text: The left ventricle receives blood through the tricuspid valve

options.label: C.
options.text: The left ventricle pumps blood to systemic circulation

options.label: D.
options.text: The left ventricle pushes blood out through the aortic valve

options.label: E.
options.text: The left ventricle receives blood from the left atrium

correct_answer_text: The left ventricle receives blood through the tricuspid valve

explanation.concept_text: Blood returning from the body enters the heart into the right atrium via the superior and inferior vena cava. It then flows into the right ventricle through the tricuspid valve, and then through the pulmonary valve and pulmonary arteries to receive oxygen from the pulmonary circulation. This blood returns to the heart through the pulmonary veins, into the left atrium , and then through the mitral (aka bicuspid) valve into the left ventricle . Blood from here is pumped to the systemic circulation – and by extension, the tissues of the body – through the aortic valve and out the aorta. Since the left ventricle must create enough force for blood to be pushed out to the entire body, it has a thick muscular wall. Remember that the heart is a muscle and has many things in common with all the other muscles of the body. For example, every time the heart beats, it does so because of an action potential. However, the action potentials that contract the heart do not originate from an external nerve, instead, they are generated by the sinoatrial (SA) node, sometimes referred to as the pacemaker of the heart. Remember that the left ventricle receives blood from the pulmonary vein , which carries the highest concentration of oxygenated blood in circulation. In contrast, the pulmonary artery carries the lowest concentration of oxygenated blood. The image below details the structure of the heart and the path taken by the blood. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The wall of the left ventricle is the thickest of the heart – This option is incorrect because this is a true statement. As oxygenated blood arrives at the left atrium via the pulmonary vein, it is pumped to the left ventricle through the mitral valve. The left ventricle must then create enough force for this blood to be pumped through the body’s largest blood vessel (aorta) and to be carried out to oxygenate the entire body. To generate this much force, the left ventricle has a thick muscular wall. Option C. The left ventricle pumps blood to systemic circulation – This option is incorrect because this is a true statement. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood to the systemic circulation for the entire body to use. In the capillaries (very thin blood vessels) of the tissues, oxygen and nutrients are released from the blood, and carbon dioxide is absorbed. From there, carbon dioxide and other waste products are carried to the heart via the superior and inferior vena cava. Option D. The left ventricle pushes blood out through the aortic valve – This option is incorrect because this is a true statement. For oxygenated blood to reach the aorta to be distributed throughout the body, it passes through the aortic valve. Immediately after, the aortic valve closes to prevent the backflow of blood into the left ventricle. The aorta is an artery, and it has the highest blood pressure of any blood vessel because it carries the entire blood volume of each ventricular contraction. The aorta travels upward the throat and curves down toward the pelvis – all while branching off to smaller arteries for delivery of oxygenated blood to the entire body. Option E. The left ventricle receives blood from the left atrium – This option is incorrect because this is a true statement. This is a crucial step in the cardiac cycle as it bridges the pulmonary circulation with the systemic circulation. That is, the left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation and the left ventricle pumps it out to the body’s systemic circulation.

question.text: Which of the following biomes are characterized by the highest amount of biodiversity and heavy rainfall?

explanation.concept_text: The tropical rainforest biome , as implied by the name, is characterized by significant rainfall, many tall trees, and temperatures that remain high. Tropical rainforests are located near the equator, which is the region of the earth receiving the most sunlight throughout the year. As such, photosynthesis is occurring at a much higher rate and there is an abundance of energy stored in plant vegetation. This abundance of nutrients combined with heavy rainfall has allowed rainforests to develop the highest amount of biodiversity than any other biome. That is, tropical rainforests have the greatest number of plant, animal, and microorganism species than any other biome. Therefore, Option A, Tropical rainforest , is the correct answer. Recall that primary producers such as plants and trees are at the lowest trophic level and provide the basis for biodiversity. Most animals live in trees because of the abundance of food, while also making it easier to avoid large terrestrial predators. The graph below illustrates the characteristic precipitation and temperatures of the various biomes. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Taiga – This option is incorrect because the taiga biome (aka boreal forest) has cold winters and little precipitation, which falls in the form of snow. This biome consists of coniferous forests (trees with needles, as opposed to leaves). This is the largest terrestrial biome and hosts animals such as bears, beavers, rabbits, and owls. Option C. Tundra – This option is incorrect because this biome has very low temperatures with little precipitation. There is very little vegetation as deeper soil is permafrost. Consequently, trees are not common in the tundra – the vegetation mostly consists of grasses, mosses, lichens, and shrubs. A few of the animals that live in the tundra are polar bears, wolves, rodents, and caribou. Option D. Savannas – This option is incorrect . Savannas (aka tropical grasslands) are characterized by high temperatures and less precipitation compared to tropical rainforests (but more than deserts). This biome consists of grasslands with scattered trees that serve as a vital food source for ungulate animals such as elephants, giraffes, and hippos. Option E. Temperate grasslands – This option is incorrect because this biome (also commonly known as prairies) receives little precipitation. As the name suggests, this biome is temperate in climate and does not see drastic fluctuations in temperature or precipitation. The North American prairie is a great example of a temperate grassland. Some of the animals found in this biome are prairie dogs, birds, reptiles, and large grazing mammals such as bison. As the name of this biome implies, grass is by far the most common organism in the prairie biome.

question.text: A cancer researcher wants to track a p53 protein related to tumor suppressor functions. Which technique could be used to locate this p53 protein within a cell?

explanation.concept_text: Immunofluorescence staining is a genetic technology where a protein is tagged with a fluorescent molecule to visualize target proteins. Different techniques and tags can allow researchers to selectively locate and visualize specific proteins using a fluorescence microscope, as shown in the image below. Note that immunofluorescence staining is especially useful when locating proteins inside a cell, without destroying the cell itself. A common mistake for this question is to pick Western Blotting. Indeed, Western Blotting is a technique used to measure protein quantities in a sample, however, it is important to remember that this technique requires the cell to be lysed and the contents run through gel electrophoresis before protein quantities can be measured. Therefore, Option C , Immunofluorescence staining , is the correct answer as it can be used to locate the p53 protein within a cell . CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. ELISA – This option is incorrect because ELISA cannot help researchers visually locate a protein. ELISA stands for Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay, and it is a technique used to determine if a specific antigen is present in a sample. This makes it useful as a diagnostic tool when diagnosing certain diseases like HIV and Lyme disease. ELISA works by separating the antibodies from the blood of a person and placing them in a microtiter plate containing antigens for a disease of interest. If the antibodies bind to the antigen, the sample will change color, indicating a positive result and the person is a carrier of the disease. If the person were not a carrier, their blood would not contain antibodies matching the antigen of interest. Option B. Polymerase Chain Reaction – This option is incorrect because PCR cannot be used in the detection of proteins. PCR stands for Polymerase Chain Reaction and is used to create millions of copies of DNA for analysis. PCR heavily relies on the Taq polymerase protein to function, however, PCR itself is not used for the detection of proteins within a cell. The three steps of DNA replication using PCR are denaturation, primer annealing, and elongation. Denaturation uses heat to separate the DNA into single-stranded DNA (ssDNA). Annealing uses short DNA molecules known as primers to stick to the area of interest on the ssDNA. Finally, during elongation, the enzyme Taq polymerase uses the ssDNA as a template and adds the complementary nucleotides in the 5’ to 3’ direction. Option D. Microarrays – This option is incorrect because DNA microarrays are not used to locate proteins. Instead, DNA microarrays are a powerful tool to study gene expression. While it gives cues on gene expression and therefore proteins that are present in a cell, they do not help locate a specific protein inside of a cell. Microarrays are used to convert mRNA to complementary DNA or cDNA. The collection of cDNA is washed over the array with many wells containing DNA probes of interest in known positions. When the cDNA hybridizes with these probes, the array can then be examined with fluorescence to identify which cDNA sequences were present and thus which genes were being expressed by that cell. Option E. Western blotting – This option is incorrect because western blotting is done in vitro (i.e., takes place outside of a cell). Western blotting is indeed used to quantify proteins in a sample, however, remember that the question is asking for a technique to locate proteins within a cell – not measure how much of it is present. Western blotting aims to detect specific proteins by denaturing them, attaching a negative charge, and then performing a specific kind of electrophoresis known as SDS PAGE. The desired protein, if present in the sample, will move a known distance due to having a known length. Antibody tags are then used to visualize exactly where the protein has moved to in the gel to determine if it is present.

question.text: An E. Coli cell culture is radioactively labeled with sulfur and the cells are then lysed. Where would the radioactive label most likely be found?

explanation.concept_text: Sulfur is most likely to be found in proteins, as shown in the image below. To be exact, the amino acids cysteine and methionine contain sulfur. The disulfide bridges formed between sulfurs on two cysteines on a polypeptide contribute to a protein’s tertiary structure. By cross-linking distant parts of the polypeptide, disulfide bonds contribute to the overall stability and help maintain the three-dimensional shape of the protein. Sulfur is distinctly not found in other biological macromolecules such as nucleotides, lipids, or carbohydrates. Therefore, Option B , Proteins , is the correct answer. This is also a good opportunity to recall that methionine is the amino acid associated with the AUG start codon. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Fats – This option is incorrect because common fat molecules such as triglycerides and phospholipids do not contain any sulfur atoms. Fats fall under the larger category of lipids, primarily composed of hydrocarbons. One common example of lipids is triglycerides, which consist of glycerol and three fatty acid chains. Glycerol is an organic molecule made up of three carbons and three hydroxyl groups. Fatty acids are made up of long hydrocarbon chains attached to a carboxylic acid. None of the structures in fats contain sulfur atoms, thus this option is incorrect. Option C. Carbohydrates – This option is incorrect because common carbohydrate molecules such as glucose, glycogen, lactose, etc. do not contain any sulfur atoms. Carbohydrates are made up of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. As a result, within carbohydrate molecules, there is roughly one water molecule for every carbon molecule. Hence the name carbo - hydrate, meaning carbon water. The monomer of carbohydrates is a monosaccharide, and the polymer is a polysaccharide. Option D. Nucleic acids – This option is incorrect because nucleic acids such as DNA and RNA do not contain any sulfur atoms. Nucleic acids are responsible for the storage of genetic information and protein synthesis. The monomer of nucleic acids (the nucleotide) is composed of a phosphate group, a five-carbon sugar, and a nitrogenous base. Nucleotides on the same strand hold onto each other via phosphodiester bonds to form the sugar-phosphate backbone of the nucleic acid strand. DNA is double-stranded with the strands running anti-parallel, whereas RNA is usually single-stranded. DNA and RNA further differ in their five-carbon sugar (deoxyribose vs ribose, respectively) in addition to some of their nitrogenous bases. None of the structures in nucleic acids contain sulfur atoms, thus this option is incorrect. Option E. Phospholipids – This option is incorrect because phospholipids do not contain sulfur. Phospholipids are comprised of one phosphate group and two fatty acids (hence the suffix lipids) attached to a glycerol backbone, none of which contain sulfur in their structure. Phospholipids are a classic example of an amphipathic molecule, meaning that the molecule has both hydrophilic and hydrophobic parts (phosphate head and fatty acid chains, respectively). Phospholipids spontaneously form a phospholipid bilayer when suspended in liquid. The hydrophilic phosphate heads on the outer layer face the fluid of the aqueous environment outside the cell, and the inner layer phospholipids face the intracellular fluid. This allows the hydrophobic fatty acid chains of both layers to face each other internally, minimizing their exposure to water.

question.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding the ovarian cycle?

options.label: A.
options.text: There is a surge of progesterone in the follicular phase, causing menstruation to cease

options.label: B.
options.text: The thickness of the uterine wall is at its peak during ovulation

options.label: C.
options.text: If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum disintegrates into a polar body

options.label: E.
options.text: Ovulation occurs due to a peak in LH levels

correct_answer_text: Ovulation occurs due to a peak in LH levels

explanation.concept_text: It is important to have a good grasp of the diagram below for the test. The ovarian cycle lasts 28 days and can be divided into three general stages: the follicular stage, ovulation, and the luteal stage. The follicular stage lasts approximately 14 days and begins on the first day of menstruation (day 1 of the cycle). During the follicular stage, luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) are released by the anterior pituitary gland, which leads to follicle development in the ovaries and stimulates the ovaries to release estrogen. A surge of estrogen near day 12-13 causes a surge of LH, which then triggers ovulation. Ovulation occurs on day 14 of the cycle and involves the rupture of the maturing follicle and the release of a secondary oocyte. Ovulation is caused by a sudden surge of LH . The released oocyte now travels down the fallopian tube (aka oviduct) toward the uterus to be implanted if fertilized by a sperm cell. Fertilization typically takes place in the fallopian tube. The luteal phase begins immediately after ovulation and lasts approximately 14 days. The erupted follicle carrying the immature oocyte is now empty and called the corpus luteum (meaning yellow body). During the luteal phase, estrogen and progesterone are secreted by the corpus luteum, which causes the thickening of the uterine wall. This occurs as the body prepares for the possible implantation of a fertilized egg. Estrogen and progesterone have inhibitory roles on the pituitary gland and prevent it from releasing FSH and LH. This ensures that no other follicle will begin developing during the luteal phase. When a fertilized egg implants into the uterine wall, it will release the human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which in turn will maintain the corpus luteum and thus maintain the levels of progesterone being released, all to maintain the thickness of the uterine wall. If there is no fertilization, the corpus luteum degenerates, estrogen and progesterone levels decrease, and the uterine wall starts shedding, marking the initiation of menstruation. The image below provides a visualization to further help understand the concepts of the ovarian cycle. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. There is a surge of progesterone in the follicular phase, causing menstruation to cease – This option is incorrect because the progesterone surge occurs during the luteal phase to prepare the uterine wall for potential implantation following ovulation. Remember that progesterone has an inhibitory effect on FSH and LH. As such, whenever there is a surge in progesterone, there will also be an inhibition of FSH and LH. However, FSH and LH have very important roles in the follicular phase (before ovulation) and should only be inhibited during the luteal phase (after ovulation). Option B. The thickness of the uterine wall is at its peak during ovulation – This option is incorrect because the uterine wall reaches its thickest point toward the end of the ovarian cycle in conjunction with a progesterone surge, which is after ovulation. The thickening of the uterine wall serves to supply nutrient-rich blood to the fertilized egg that may attach to the uterine wall toward the end of each ovarian cycle. Consider that after being fertilized in the fallopian tube, an egg needs roughly 7 days to travel to the uterus. To maximize the chances of successful implantation by a fertilized egg, the uterine wall should be at its peak thickness around the time the fertilized egg is expected to arrive at the uterus. It would NOT be preferable for the uterus to be at its thickest during ovulation because that is long before the expected arrival of the fertilized egg at the uterus. Option C. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum disintegrates into a polar body – This option is incorrect . While it is true that the corpus luteum disintegrates if no fertilization occurs, it does not turn into a polar body. Recall that females are born with a set number of primary oocytes arrested in prophase 1. Years later, after reaching puberty and having sexually matured, one oocyte a month is selected to go through meiosis and develop into a follicle. A polar body forms once a month due to this meiotic phase of oogenesis. It is a small, non-functional cell created because of an uneven divide of cell components as part of the last steps of meiosis. Option D. Follicular development is hormone-independent – This option is incorrect because follicular development is hormone-dependent and is stimulated by the follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) which is released by the anterior pituitary gland. In females, FSH stimulates the maturation of ovarian follicles to secrete estrogen. In males, FSH stimulates spermatogenesis (sperm cell production) and maturation of the seminiferous tubules. FSH is a peptide hormone, meaning it is composed of a short chain of amino acids. Peptide hormones cannot diffuse through the cell membrane. Instead, they bind to cell membrane receptors located on the surface of the target cell, which then triggers a signaling pathway inside the cell via secondary messengers.

question.text: Cellulose and glycogen are both examples of what type of molecule?

explanation.concept_text: There are four major biological macromolecules : carbohydrates, proteins, nucleic acids, and lipids. Each of the four macromolecules is made up of monomers that covalently bond to form larger polymers. Carbohydrate monomers are called monosaccharides, and they bond together via glycosidic bonds to form their polymer, polysaccharides. Protein monomers are known as amino acids and bond together via peptide bonds to form the protein polymer, a polypeptide. Nucleic Acid polymers are made up of nucleotide monomers bonded via phosphodiester bonds. Lastly, lipid polymers are made up of fatty acid and glycerol monomers that bond together via ester bonds.
