This question mentions cellulose and glycogen, which are types of polysaccharides. Recall that a polysaccharide is the polymer of carbohydrates. Therefore, Option A , Carbohydrates , is the correct option. Cellulose is a crucial component of plant cell walls, and in fact, cellulose is the most abundant organic molecule on earth. As shown in the image below, cellulose is a polysaccharide made up of repeating units of beta-glucose. These repeating units are linked together in a linear (i.e., unbranched) way to form cellulose chains. Moreover, these chains neatly stack in parallel and are held in place by the formation of hydrogen bonds between adjacent chains. This gives cellulose a strong and rigid structure and is the reason cellulose is the major component of plant cell walls. Glycogen is made up of alpha-glucose monomers and serves as the primary energy storage molecule in the body. Unlike cellulose (which is unbranched), glycogen has a highly branched structure and, therefore, is more soluble in water. This makes it especially useful as an energy-storage molecule in animals. In the body, glycogen is primarily stored in the liver and the muscles. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Proteins – This option is incorrect because cellulose and glycogen are not proteins. Proteins are one of the four major macromolecules. Every protein polymer is made up of hundreds of monomers called amino acids. There are 20 distinct amino acids, each one with a unique side chain, and each amino acid is bonded to the next via a peptide bond. This high degree of variability gives each protein its unique structure and function. Hormones, enzymes, antibodies, and transport proteins are just a few examples of the types of proteins that carry out a wide array of functions within an organism. Cellulose and glycogen are carbohydrate polymers - not centrosomes. Option C. Nucleic Acids – This option is incorrect because cellulose and glycogen are not nucleic acids. Nucleic acids are molecules that store and transmit genetic information and they are made up of monomers called nucleotides. Nucleotides include a five-carbon sugar in their structure (recall that sugars are carbohydrates), however, every nucleotide also includes one phosphate group and one nitrogenous base in its structure (neither of which is a carbohydrate). No nucleotide would function properly without all three of these components in its structure. To summarize, nucleic acids do include carbohydrates in their structure, but they also include other non-carbohydrate parts; therefore, nucleic acids as a whole cannot be characterized as carbohydrates. Furthermore, cellulose and glycogen do not contain nucleotides in their structure. Option D. Centrosomes – This option is incorrect because centrosomes are not carbohydrates. Instead, centrosomes are organelles that play a vital role in cell division. A centrosome is composed of two centrioles, oriented perpendicular to each other. Anchored to each centriole, several microtubules branch off toward the center of the cell to form the mitotic spindle for cell division. As such, centrosomes are considered microtubule-organizing centers (MTOCs). Cellulose and glycogen are carbohydrate polymers – not centrosomes. Option E. Lipids – This option is incorrect because lipids are not carbohydrates. Lipids are distinct from carbohydrates despite both being essential macromolecules. While carbohydrates are hydrophilic and built from linked sugar monomers, lipids are hydrophobic and more diverse in structure. Some lipids contain fatty acid chains and a glycerol group. Other lipids, like phospholipids, include a phosphate group. Other types of lipids, like steroids, bear none of the structures mentioned above, yet, are considered lipids because they are hydrophobic and water-insoluble. In contrast, cellulose and glycogen are not lipids – they are carbohydrate polymers.

question.text: Which process directly causes an excitatory response in skeletal vertebrate muscle?

options.label: B.
options.text: Increase of acetylcholine in the cytosol

options.label: C.
options.text: Influx of calcium in the cytosol

options.label: D.
options.text: Rise of sodium in the synaptic cleft

options.label: E.
options.text: Testosterone secretion from the pituitary gland

correct_answer_text: Influx of calcium in the cytosol

explanation.concept_text: Skeletal muscle is a type of striated muscle tissue responsible for voluntary movement, as opposed to smooth and cardiac muscle, which contract involuntarily. To voluntarily contract a muscle, the nervous system needs to induce a chain of events that shorten the sarcomere (basic contractile unit of muscle fiber). The term “excitatory response,” mentioned in this question, refers to this chain of events that lead to muscle contraction . To shorten the sarcomere, the nervous system initiates an action potential that travels down motor neurons and reaches the neuromuscular junction of the desired muscle, that is, the space between the presynaptic motor neuron and postsynaptic muscle fiber. When the action potential reaches the axon terminal (the very end of a neuron), it releases the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) into the neuromuscular junction. ACh then binds to Ach receptors located on the muscle cell membrane, which in turn causes ligand-gated ion channels located on the muscle cell membrane to open and allow sodium ions (Na + ) to influx into the muscle cell. As a result, the muscle cell depolarizes (membrane potential changes from negative to positive) and creates a new action potential along the T-tubules. This new action potential reaches the sarcoplasmic reticulum and triggers the release of calcium ions (Ca 2+ ) into the cytosol of the muscle cell. During a muscle’s relaxed state, the thick and thin filaments cannot bind because tropomyosin blocks the active binding between the two filaments. The calcium ions bind to troponin proteins located on the actin (thin) filaments of the sarcomere. This binding causes tropomyosin to undergo a conformational change and exposes the actin-myosin binding site, which allows for the two filaments to bind, and therefore, muscle contraction is achieved. The influx of calcium ions in the cytosol of the muscle cell is what induces the sarcomere's thick and thin filaments to slide (which is the basis of muscle contraction). Therefore, Option C , Influx of calcium in the cytosol , is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Less potassium outside the cell – This option is incorrect . Indeed, potassium is involved in the excitation of muscle, however, for excitation to occur, potassium levels outside the cell need to be higher than inside the cell, not lower . Recall that as sodium ions pass through the ion channels toward the inside of the muscle cell, potassium ions subsequently exit the muscle cell toward the neuromuscular junction as part of the action potential. If enough ions participate in this exchange (i.e., Na + in and K + out), depolarization will occur, and a second action potential will begin along the T-tubules. Option B. Increase of acetylcholine in the cytosol – This option is incorrect because acetylcholine (ACh) never crosses the cell membrane into the cytosol of the muscle cell. Instead, ACh binds to the acetylcholine receptors on the surface of the muscle cell. This opens the ion channels and allows for depolarization to occur and the excitation process to continue. The acetylcholine bound to the cell surface receptor is eventually broken down and recycled in the synapse. Option D. Rise of sodium in the synaptic cleft – This option is incorrect because the mere rise of sodium ions in the synaptic cleft is not enough to trigger an excitatory response. No matter how high the sodium concentration in the synaptic cleft, there must first be an influx of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft for the ion channels to open and allow for depolarization. Remember that sodium ions need to rush into the cell – not the synapse between cells – for there to be depolarization. Option E. Testosterone secretion from the pituitary gland – This option is incorrect for multiple reasons. Although testosterone may indirectly influence some attributes of muscle such as overall muscle mass, testosterone itself does not trigger an “excitatory response” in muscles – it plays no role in muscle contraction itself. Moreover, this answer option claims that testosterone is secreted by the pituitary gland, which is untrue. Testosterone is a steroid hormone primarily responsible for sexual development in males and muscle and bone growth in both sexes. It is not secreted by the pituitary gland, but instead, by the testes and the adrenal gland.

question.text: Lobe-finned fish with lungs directly preceded which category of organisms?

explanation.concept_text: This question tests your knowledge of the phylogenetic tree of deuterostomes (shown in the figure below). It is important to memorize this tree and be able to a) recall the order of taxonomic groups and b) recall identifying features of each taxonomic group, such as a notochord, jaw, lungs, amniotic egg, etc. Let us first discuss a few things that will aid your understanding of phylogenetic trees and help you tackle questions like this one. Now, let us tackle the question at hand. Lobe-finned fish are characterized by their paired, fleshy pectoral, and pelvic fins, each articulated via a single bone. When reviewing the phylogenetic tree below, it is observed that lobe-finned fish exhibit lungs because they appeared after the corresponding node. Note that the description “with lungs,” written in the question, is technically correct, however, it is not necessary. Do not let this description shift your focus to the lungfish group. Further analysis of the tree reveals that lobe-finned fish with lungs directly precede amphibians. Therefore, Option A . A mphibians is correct. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Reptiles – This option is incorrect because reptiles are preceded by amphibians, not lobe-finned fish with lungs. As seen in the figure above, reptiles possess an amniotic egg . Without this morphological feature, reptiles would not have been able to become fully terrestrial because of the need to keep embryos from drying out in terrestrial environments. Another conclusion drawn using the figure above is that lobe-finned fish are more closely related to amphibians than they are to reptiles. While lobe-finned fish with lungs appeared earlier compared to reptiles, they do not directly precede reptiles. Option C. Lampreys – This option is incorrect because lampreys are preceded by hagfishes, not lobe-finned fish with lungs. Moreover, lampreys originate earlier in the phylogenetic tree when compared to lobe-finned fish with lungs. Lobe-finned fish with lungs cannot precede lampreys since lampreys do not possess a jaw or lungs – two features notable present in lobe-finned fish with lungs. Lampreys appeared before lobe-finned fish – not after . Option D. Humans – This option is incorrect. As mammals, humans are preceded by reptiles and birds, not lobe-finned fish with lungs. By referencing the phylogenetic tree above, it is evident that mammals and reptiles are separated by only one node. As such, mammals and reptiles are much more closely related to each other than either of them is to lobe-finned fish. The main distinguishing feature between mammals and reptiles is that reptiles lack mammary glands. In contrast, lobe-finned fish not only lack mammary glands, but they also lack four legs and an amniotic egg. Therefore, humans (fall under mammals) are preceded by reptiles, not lobe-finned fish with lungs. Option E. Sharks – This option is incorrect because sharks are preceded by lampreys, not lobe-finned fish with lungs. Sharks fall under the taxonomic group cartilaginous fishes because their skeleton is made up mostly of cartilage, not bone. This allows for a lighter body and more agile movements. Cartilaginous fish appeared before lobe-finned fish – not after .

question.text: Twins can differ in their level of genetic similarity depending on the method of fertilization. Which of the following would lead to dizygotic twins being born?

options.label: A.
options.text: Separation of blastomeres in a single zygote

options.label: B.
options.text: Separation of an egg fertilized by two sperm

options.label: C.
options.text: Fertilization of two eggs by two different sperm

options.label: D.
options.text: Fertilization of two eggs by one sperm

correct_answer_text: Fertilization of two eggs by two different sperm

explanation.concept_text: Twins are two offspring resulting from a single pregnancy. The two main types are monozygotic and dizygotic. Recall that a zygote is formed by the fusion of strictly one ovum and one sperm cell (no more, no less). When tackling questions regarding twins, it may be useful to break each word into its parts and recognize that monozygotic means one zygote , and dizygotic means two zygotes . Put differently, monozygotic twins arise from only one egg and one sperm cell, whereas dizygotic twins arise from two eggs and two sperm. Therefore, Option C . Fertilization of two eggs by two different sperm is the correct answer. This concept is shown in the figure below. To further elaborate on the differences: CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Separation of blastomeres in a single zygote – This option is incorrect . Recall that the term blastomere refers to any cell being created during the cleavage stage of embryogenesis. If a blastomere were separated from a zygote, as this answer option suggests, it would result in monozygotic twins. Option B. Separation of an egg fertilized by two sperm – This option is incorrect because an egg can be fertilized by only one sperm cell. Although millions of sperm cells are competing to fertilize the egg, it is not possible for multiple sperm to fuse with the same egg. The fast block and slow block are mechanisms put in place to prevent polyspermy. Immediately after the egg’s cell membrane has fused with that of the sperm, the fast block takes place. This involves the quick depolarization of the egg from a negative to a positive charge, which prevents the fusion of additional sperm cells. This depolarization then triggers the slow block: the exocytosis of numerous cortical granules that create a fertilization envelope and make polyspermy permanently impossible. If polyspermy were to occur, the embryo would not be viable. Option D. Fertilization of two eggs by one sperm – This option is incorrect because one sperm can fertilize only one egg. It is not possible for a single sperm to fertilize two different eggs. Remember that all gametes are haploid. Once a haploid sperm fuses with a haploid egg, a diploid zygote is formed. Not only would it be functionally impossible for one sperm cell to fertilize two eggs – because fertilization involves the fusion of cell membranes of the gametes – but it would also be genetically impossible because a haploid sperm cell only contains enough chromosomes to give rise to one fully-functional diploid organism.

question.text: The plasma membrane is predominantly composed of which macromolecules?

explanation.concept_text: Phospholipids and proteins are the two most common macromolecules in the plasma membrane. Therefore, Option C . Phospholipids and proteins is the correct answer. Phospholipids make up the bilayer of the cell membrane. The hydrophilic phosphate heads of the outer membrane face the extracellular liquid and the hydrophilic phosphate heads of the inner layer face the cytosol. This leaves the hydrophobic fatty acids of both layers to face each other and minimizes exposure to water. Proteins are present in the membrane to give additional functionality such as cell recognition, cell signaling, enzymatic activity, and structural integrity. In addition, cholesterol molecules embedded within the plasma membrane help regulate the fluidity and permeability of the membrane. Less frequently, carbohydrates may also be attached to lipids (forming glycolipids) and proteins (forming glycoproteins) resulting in additional functionality ranging from signaling to structure (e.g., attachment of collagen). The plasma membrane is also referred to as the “ fluid mosaic model ” because of the numerous different components embedded in the phospholipid bilayer (e.g. proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrates) resembling a mosaic, and because of its fluid structure - none of the phospholipids are rigidly bound to each other, so phospholipids are constantly sliding laterally within the layer and are free to move around – hence the term “fluid.” The fluid mosaic model plays a crucial role in the membrane’s selective permeability, flexibility, enzymatic activity, and cell signaling. CC BY 3.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Proteins and glycolipids – This option is incorrect because glycolipids do not make up the majority of the cell membrane. The molecules that predominately make up the plasma membrane are phospholipids, which form the bilayer, and proteins as they contribute to cell recognition and signaling. Although glycolipids are found in the plasma membrane, they are not as common as phospholipids and proteins. Glycoproteins are made up of proteins and carbohydrates and serve numerous functions for the cell membrane such as cell recognition for immune responses, cell adhesion, signal transduction for secondary messengers, Option B. Phospholipids and DNA – This option is incorrect because DNA does not make up the majority of the cell membrane. The molecules that predominately make up the plasma membrane are phospholipids, which form the bilayer, and proteins as they contribute to cell recognition and signaling. No DNA is found in the plasma membrane. DNA is the instruction manual of an entire organism, and it is protected with a very high degree of priority. Otherwise, mutations will occur much more frequently, and an entire cascade of negative consequences such as disease will follow. In eukaryotic cells, DNA is found only within the nucleus, protected by the nuclear membrane. It is important to understand that DNA does not serve as a structural molecule but, instead, stores genetic information. Option D. Cholesterol and triglycerides – This option is incorrect because triglycerides are not a component of the plasma membrane. Triglycerides do not contain any hydrophilic components. An entirely hydrophobic molecule will find it very hard to remain stable in the plasma membrane. Moreover, triglycerides are relatively large molecules (compared to phospholipids), which would make it even harder to remain stable within the plasma membrane. The molecules that predominately make up the plasma membrane are phospholipids, which form the bilayer, and proteins as they contribute to cell recognition and signaling. Option E. Cholesterol and glycoproteins – This option is incorrect . Although both of these molecules are found in the plasma membrane, neither makes up the majority of the plasma membrane. The molecules that predominately make up the plasma membrane are phospholipids, which form the bilayer, and proteins as they contribute to cell recognition and signaling. Nevertheless, cholesterol plays a crucial role in the plasma membrane. Cholesterol regulates membrane fluidity and facilitates cell signaling.

question.text: All of the following have mitochondria EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Often referred to as “the powerhouse of the cell” mitochondria are organelles found in most eukaryotic cells and serve to convert food into adenosine triphosphate (ATP), a usable form of energy for the body. As such, any cell or tissue that requires energy to perform its function is likely to have mitochondria (hint: this ends up being most, but not all, of the cells in our body). One notable example of a cell lacking mitochondria is red blood cells (erythrocytes). The main function of red blood cells is to carry oxygen to all the tissues of the body. To achieve this, hundreds of millions of hemoglobin molecules are tightly packed into each red blood cell. The lack of not just mitochondria, but all organelles, conserves valuable inner-cell volume and allows red blood cells to have such a large quantity of oxygen-carrying hemoglobin molecules in their structure. Therefore, Option D , Red blood cells , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Muscle cells – This option is incorrect. Muscle cells are very energy intensive. Think about how much work you are putting your muscles through every day just to exist and move around. This requires tremendous amounts of energy in the form of ATP. Recall that the sarcomere – the functional unit of muscle fiber – heavily relies on ATP to function. ATP is used for the actual contraction of the sarcomere and then again one ATP molecule is used per myosin head to reset the sarcomere back to its relaxed state. Therefore, mitochondria are a crucial component of each muscle cell. Option B. Nerve cells – This option is incorrect . When it comes to energy consumption, no other organ comes close to the brain. Indeed, the brain is the highest energy-consuming organ in the body. This is because significant amounts of ATP are required to maintain the ion gradients that contribute to the creation of action potentials and transmission of nerve signals. Thus, nerve cells would be rendered useless without the presence of their mitochondria. Option C. Brown fat cells – This option is incorrect because brown fat cells are packed with lots of mitochondria. Unlike white fat, which mainly serves as energy storage, brown fat specializes in heat production using thermogenesis. In other words, brown fat keeps your body warm when you get cold. To support this energy-demanding process, lots of mitochondria are needed inside of brown fat cells. Option E. Lymphocytes – This option is incorrect because the functions performed by lymphocytes are very energy-intensive. Antigen presentation, cytokine production, and cell signaling are just a few of the many energy-intensive functions performed by activated lymphocytes.

question.text: A cross is performed between true breeding spiked plants and true breeding smooth plants, resulting in all spiked F1 offspring. If the F1 generation is crossed with itself to produce the F2 generation, then the F2 generation has a ratio of 3:1 spiked to smooth. If the F1 generation is crossed with a smooth plant, what would be the ratio of spiked to smooth in their offspring?

explanation.concept_text: A " true breeding ” organism, otherwise known as “ purebred ,” is homozygous for a particular trait, meaning it has two identical alleles for that gene (e.g., ff or JJ). At this point we do not know which of the two presented alleles – spiked vs smooth – is the dominant one. Crossing two true breeding organisms is an excellent method for determining dominance between two genes. Once the cross is performed, it is observed that all the offspring carry the spiked phenotype . Therefore, the allele for spiked is determined to be the dominant one. Let us suppose that the “G” allele refers to the dominant allele for the spiked surface while the “g” allele refers to the recessive allele for the smooth surface. Examining the genotypes of the purebreds, we see that the purebred spiked plant is GG while the purebred smooth plant is gg. As seen in the Punnett Square below, the F1 generation, GG x gg , will all have the Gg genotype. Because the spiked surface (“G” allele) is dominant to the smooth surface, the F1 generation will express only the spiked trait. Knowing the genotypes of the F1 generation, we can then consider the cross between the F1 generation with the purebred smooth plant: Gg x gg . The Punnett square below shows the resulting genotypes. Now, we can examine the phenotypes resulting from this cross. Gg will have the spiked trait and gg will have the smooth trait. These phenotypes each appear twice in the Punnett square, making the ratio of spiked to smooth offspring 2:2, which simplifies to 1:1. Therefore, Option C. 1:1, is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 1:3 – This option is incorrect because the F1 generation is comprised of heterozygote plants since both parents were pure breeds (homozygous) for their traits. Since all F1 plants are spiked, this means that spiked is the dominant allele. This means that when we cross a heterozygote plant with a smooth plant (homozygous recessive using a Punnett square, we get 50% heterozygotes (spiked phenotype) and 50% homozygous recessive (smooth phenotype). Therefore, for the ratio of spiked(dominant) to smooth(recessive), we get a 2:2 ratio. Option B. 2:1 – This option is incorrect because when we cross a heterozygote plant with a smooth plant (homozygous recessive using a Punnett square, we get 50% heterozygotes (spiked phenotype) and 50% homozygous recessive (smooth phenotype). Therefore, for the ratio of spiked(dominant): smooth(recessive), we get a 2:2 ratio. Option D. 3:1 – This option is incorrect because the F1 generation is comprised of heterozygote plants since both parents were pure breeds (homozygous) for their traits. Since all F1 plants are spiked, this means that spiked is the dominant allele. This means that when we cross a heterozygote plant with a smooth plant (homozygous recessive using a Punnett square, we get 50% heterozygotes (spiked phenotype) and 50% homozygous recessive (smooth phenotype). Therefore, for the ratio of spiked(dominant) to smooth(recessive), we get a 2:2 ratio. Option E. 4:0 – This option is incorrect . A Punnett square would result in a ratio of 4:0 only if all offspring express the same trait (i.e., either all dominant or all recessive). The first Punnett square shown above (GG x gg) is an example of a 4:0 ratio.

question.text: Which of the following correctly identifies a difference between the anterior and posterior pituitary gland?

options.label: A.
options.text: The posterior pituitary is connected to the hypothalamus via a neuron while the anterior pituitary is not

options.label: B.
options.text: Only the posterior pituitary gland is stimulated by hormones from the hypothalamus

options.label: C.
options.text: The anterior pituitary releases peptide hormones while the posterior pituitary releases steroid hormones

options.label: D.
options.text: A greater variety of hormones are secreted by the posterior pituitary than the anterior pituitary

options.label: E.
options.text: The posterior pituitary releases only tropic hormones while the anterior pituitary releases only non-tropic hormones

correct_answer_text: The posterior pituitary is connected to the hypothalamus via a neuron while the anterior pituitary is not

explanation.concept_text: The pituitary gland (aka hypophysis) is at the base of the brain, just under the hypothalamus, and is divided into the anterior and posterior lobes. Each lobe regulates numerous important hormones in the body whenever it is instructed to do so by the hypothalamus. However, there are several differences between the two lobes. While both lobes release hormones to the entire body, only the anterior lobe produces said hormones by itself; the posterior lobe can only store and release hormones that have already been produced by the hypothalamus. Another difference is that while both lobes receive instructions from the hypothalamus, the anterior lobe receives these instructions via other hormones carried through blood vessels, whereas the posterior lobe receives instructions via a neuron. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer. Fun fact: this is why the posterior pituitary gland is also known as the neuro hypophysis. The posterior pituitary gland releases two hormones : ADH (antidiuretic hormone, aka vasopressin), and oxytocin. The anterior pituitary gland releases six hormones . Use the mnemonic FLAT PiG to remember them: i 6. G rowth hormone CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Only the posterior pituitary gland is stimulated by hormones from the hypothalamus – This option is incorrect because only the anterior pituitary gland is stimulated by hormones from the hypothalamus. In contrast, the posterior lobe is stimulated by electrical signals from the hypothalamus. Remember that hormones cannot travel through nerves. Because the posterior lobe is connected to the hypothalamus only via nerve tissue, it is much more efficient for the hypothalamus to use electrical impulses as opposed to hormones to instruct the posterior lobe. The opposite is true regarding the anterior lobe. Since it connects to the hypothalamus via blood vessels, hormones are the preferred means of communication. For example, the hypothalamus uses thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) to stimulate the anterior lobe to release TSH. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is used for the release of FSH and LH, and Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) is used for the release of growth hormone. Option C. The anterior pituitary releases peptide hormones while the posterior pituitary releases steroid hormones – This option is incorrect because all the hormones released by the pituitary gland (both lobes) are peptide hormones. Peptide hormones are composed of amino acids. Because they are hydrophilic and large in size, peptide hormones cannot cross the cell membrane. Instead, they function by binding to receptors on the surface of cells, which then triggers a cell signaling pathway via secondary messengers. In contrast, steroid hormones are much smaller and hydrophobic, which allows them to easily diffuse through the plasma membrane and bind to receptors within the cytoplasm or in the nucleus. Option D. A greater variety of hormones are secreted by the posterior pituitary than the anterior pituitary – This option is incorrect because the anterior pituitary releases six hormones, whereas the posterior releases two. The six hormones released by the anterior lobe are follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), prolactin, and human growth hormone (HGH). On the other hand, the two hormones released by the posterior lobe are oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone (aka vasopressin). Option E . The posterior pituitary releases only tropic hormones while the anterior pituitary releases only non-tropic hormones – A tropic hormone does not stimulate its target cell directly. Instead, a tropic hormone instructs other endocrine glands to release their own hormone. In contrast, a non-tropic hormone directly stimulates its target cell. This answer option is incorrect for two reasons. First, the hormones released by the posterior pituitary (ADH & oxytocin) are non-tropic. Additionally, the anterior pituitary releases both tropic (ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH) as well as non-tropic (growth & prolactin) hormones.

question.text: A long-distance runner has been running for several days through a desert without any food. After the muscles in her legs are depleted of all ATP, which of the following would best describe the state of her muscular filaments?

options.label: A.
options.text: Myosin head is detached from actin but not in the position for the next contraction

options.label: B.
options.text: Myosin head is attached to actin and ready for a power stroke

options.label: C.
options.text: Myosin head is attached to actin immediately after a power stroke

options.label: D.
options.text: Myosin head is detached from actin and ready to form another cross bridge

options.label: E.
options.text: Myosin head is detached from actin as tropomyosin is blocking attachment site on actin

correct_answer_text: Myosin head is attached to actin immediately after a power stroke

explanation.concept_text: Muscle tissues require the presence of ATP to function. Specifically, ATP is necessary for the proper function of the sarcomere , which is the basic functional unit of muscle tissue. The sliding filament theory states that sarcomere shortening occurs when thick and thin filaments – myosin and actin, respectively – slide toward each other (remember that acTIN = THIN). This sliding is based on temporary attachments (termed cross-bridges) between the two filaments. As we will discuss shortly, this temporary attachment between the two filaments cannot be broken without ATP. A sarcomere is said to be in a relaxed state (i.e., non-shortened) when the two filaments are not attached. Their attachment is prevented by tropomyosin, which blocks the myosin binding site and prevents myosin from creating a cross-bridge. The sliding of the two filaments is triggered by calcium ions. Once released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, calcium ions bind to troponin proteins located on the actin filament and trigger tropomyosin to move and reveal the binding sites, thus allowing myosin heads to attach. Shortly after the formation of a cross-bridge, myosin hydrolyzes an ATP molecule and performs a “power stroke” to pull the actin filament toward the center of the sarcomere. The sarcomere has now been shortened and muscle contraction has occurred. However, another ATP molecule will be required to detach the two filaments – otherwise, the cross-bridge will not detach. As seen in step (d) in the diagram below, a new ATP molecule causes the detaching of the myosin head from actin filaments, allowing the myosin head to return to its original position ready for the next power stroke. In conditions where there is no ATP available, the myosin head cannot detach from actin following a power stroke, leaving the muscle in a rigid and contracted state. Recall that, after death, the body can eventually reach a stage known as rigor mortis (meaning stiffness of death). During this state, actin and myosin cannot detach from each other because ATP production has stopped, and the body’s muscles cannot return to a non-contracted state. As a result, muscles become stiff and locked in place. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Myosin head is detached from actin but not in the position for the next contraction – This option is incorrect because detachment of the myosin head from actin requires ATP, and the question stem mentions there is no ATP available. After a myosin head attaches to actin, the release of phosphate and ADP (adenosine diphosphate) triggers the shortening of the sarcomere (aka power stroke). Remember that the two filaments remain bound together; it is only when a new ATP molecule attaches to myosin that the two filaments detach. Each new ATP molecule that attaches to a myosin head provides enough energy to drive the breaking of the cross-bridge, the formation of a new cross-bridge, and a new power stroke. In the absence of new ATP, the sarcomere would not stop after the breaking of the cross-bridge, as this option suggests; instead, the sarcomere would stop functioning after the power stroke. Option B. Myosin head is attached to actin and ready for a power stroke – This option is incorrect because, once the cross-bridge cycle begins, the power stroke is not affected by the absence of external ATP and can go to completion. This is because the formation of a new cross-bridge and the power stroke are driven by the same ATP molecule that broke the previous cross-bridge. Therefore, the absence of available ATP would not be “felt” by a sarcomere until it needs a new ATP molecule, which occurs after the power stroke has occurred. Therefore, in the absence of new ATP, the sarcomere would not stop before the power stroke, as this option suggests; instead, the sarcomere would stop functioning after the power stroke. This option corresponds to steps a) and b) in the above diagram, where previously hydrolyzed ATP is still attached to the myosin head. Option D. Myosin head is detached from actin and ready to form another crossbridge – This option is incorrect . Like Option A, if all ATP were depleted, no cross-bridge cycle would stop after the breakage of the cross-bridge, as this option suggests. Instead, the same ATP molecule that triggered the separation of the two filaments would drive the sarcomere to form a new cross bridge and also perform the power stroke. The absence of external ATP would only be “felt” by the sarcomere after the power stroke is performed (because it is at this stage that a new ATP would be needed). Detachment requires ATP and due to lack of ATP, muscle tissue would not have the chance to reach this step, let alone rest in this position permanently. This option corresponds to step e) in the diagram above. Option E. Myosin head is detached from actin as tropomyosin is blocking attachment site on actin – This option is incorrect because tropomyosin blockage can only be relieved with the presence of calcium; this option is not relevant to the presence or absence of ATP.

question.text: Which of the following signaling molecules is released by virally infected cells?

explanation.concept_text: Given the vast number of tissues and organs working together to reach homeostasis, our body parts need an effective way of communicating any problems, needs, and any event that demands attention. One important example is the case of a virally infected cell. Without an effective means of communication, the virus may quickly spread to the entire organism. If a cell is virally infected , it will produce interferons to warn nearby cells of the virus. Interferons are proteins that bind to non-infected cells and trigger a signaling cascade to produce antiviral proteins specific to the virus that induced the cascade. To further reduce the spread of the virus, interferons may also induce non-infected cells to destroy RNA and cease protein synthesis (excluding antiviral proteins). Interferons can also induce apoptosis in nearby infected cells. Because interferons are signaling molecules released by virally infected cells, Option B is the correct answer. Interferons target nearby cells; therefore, they are said to be paracrine messengers (para = nearby). In contrast, autocrine messengers bind to receptors on the same cell that released the messenger (auto = self), endocrine messengers are secreted into the bloodstream (endo = inside), and lastly, exocrine messengers are secreted into ducts such as the gallbladder or salivary glands (exo = outside). CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Immunoglobulin – This option is incorrect because immunoglobulins are not released by virally infected cells. Instead, immunoglobulins are another term for antibodies that are produced by plasma B cells. These antibodies are used to tag or inactivate a pathogen. They have a Y-shaped structure that consists of a light chain and a heavy chain, held together via disulfide bonds. Antibodies have two main regions, the constant and variable regions. The constant region of an antibody determines its class (IgA, IgM, IgD, IgE, and IgG), while the variable regions are the tips of the “Y” and give each immunoglobulin its uniqueness. While immunoglobulins have important roles in immune response, they are not released by virally infected cells, as this option suggests. Option C. Fibrin – This option is incorrect because fibrin is not a signaling molecule and it is not released by virally infected cells. Fibrin is a protein that plays a crucial role in the formation of blood clots for blood vessel repair and blood loss prevention. Upon injury, thrombocytes convert the precursor protein fibrinogen (found in blood plasma) into fibrin. Fibrin monomers then form long insoluble strands to form the blood clot. While fibrin is crucial in the body’s defense against pathogens and injury, it is NOT a signaling molecule released by virally infected cells. Option D. Perforin – This option is incorrect because perforin is not released by virally infected cells. The perforin protein is produced by cytotoxic T cells and acts by perforating the cell membrane of virally infected cells. Granzymes then enter the cell via these pores to trigger apoptosis. While perforin has roles in immune response (and specifically in virally infected cells), perforin itself is not released by virally infected cells, as this option suggests – instead, perforin is released by cytotoxic T cells. Option E. Interleukin – This option is incorrect because interleukins are cytokines (signaling proteins) that are released by various leukocytes (white blood cells) and enhance communication between immune cells. As such, interleukins serve a diverse set of roles in the body. For example, macrophages release interleukins to recruit help, dendritic cells release interleukins to communicate with T cells, and lastly, helper T cells use interleukins to activate, amplify, and regulate other cells. While both interleukins and interferons are signaling molecules, they serve different purposes. Interleukins are a means of communication between various immune cells (T cells, B cells, macrophages, etc.), whereas interferons interact directly with viral replication within infected cells.

question.text: A farm next to a lake begins to spray a new type of nutrient mix on its plants. When it rains, the nutrient mix washes away into a nearby pond. Which of the following would you expect to see in the pond over time?

explanation.concept_text: A type of pollution that can occur in large bodies of water – such as lakes, ponds, rivers, and streams – is eutrophication. Eutrophication occurs when a large body of water becomes overly enriched with certain nutrients that induce a serious imbalance in the environment. Oftentimes, phosphorus-based pesticides from nearby farms can be washed down by rainfall and contaminate a pond or lake. This in turn can cause the increased growth of bacteria such as algae and cyanobacteria known as algal bloom . These overgrown patches of algae and cyanobacteria respire and deplete oxygen which leads to many organisms below the surface of water dying of oxygen starvation. Therefore, Option E, Algal bloom , is the correct answer. Note: Although eutrophication can occur naturally, human activity has accelerated it significantly. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Primary succession – This option is incorrect because primary succession is the process by which life forms in an environment that has never supported life previously (e.g., a glacier, rocky terrain, newly cooled down lava). During primary succession, a pioneer species (e.g., bacteria, lichen, and fungi) is the first colonizer and serves as the foundation for larger and more complex organisms to eventually join. Remember that primary succession does not require the creation of new species. Most of the species that eventually colonize the new environment have existed before a given primary succession event. Primary succession does not occur through the introduction of chemicals in an environment – remember that in this question the introduction of chemicals is accelerating the growth of existing organisms, therefore, this option is incorrect. Option B. Outbreeding – This option is incorrect because outbreeding would not be the result of nutrient mix washing into a pond. Instead, outbreeding occurs when unrelated partners breed and produce offspring with new allele combinations. In contrast, inbreeding is the opposite. Inbreeding involves the breeding of two relatives, resulting in an increased expression of harmful recessive traits. This concept is completely unrelated to the process of eutrophication in the question. Option C. Artificial selection – This option is incorrect because artificial selection does not occur through the introduction of chemicals in a pond. Artificial selection is a process usually carried out intentionally by humans to increase certain favorable traits within a population. One common example of artificial selection is the breeding of a new dog breed. This is done through selective breeding – not the introduction of chemicals in a pond. Option D. Habituation – This option is incorrect because habituation is a learned behavior that allows an animal to disregard inconsequential and repetitive stimuli. The scenario provided by the question does involve a certain stimulus (introduction of nutrient mix), however, the stimulus is NOT repetitive. More importantly, the stimulus is NOT inconsequential, given that it is toxic to most animals experiencing the stimulus. One example of habituation is when anemones do not react to being repeatedly poked with a stick. Usually, anemones will react when they contact something because it may be food, but after being repeatedly poked, the anemone learns that the stick is not food. This concept is related to animal behavior and is completely separate from the ecological topic of eutrophication.

question.text: Given that two parents both have the DdEe genotype, what are the chances that an offspring will be recessive for both traits?

explanation.concept_text: This question is testing your ability to analyze a dihybrid scenario. In other words, two genes are being analyzed simultaneously. There are two methods to solve this problem. One method is the dihybrid Punnett square which is essentially a 4x4 Punnett square. However, it is labor and time-intensive to prepare this square. For all intents and purposes of this test, you should always avoid drawing out a dihybrid Punnet square (4x4 square). Instead, a simpler and faster way of tackling dihybrid questions like this is to examine the odds of each allele combination independently . That is, build one monohybrid square (2x2) for alleles “D” and “d” and then another monohybrid square (2x2) for alleles “E” and “e”. The question mentions that both parents have the DdEe genotype. Instead of writing out the dihybrid cross DdEe x DdEe, let us split this into two monohybrid crosses: Dd x Dd and Ee x Ee. Let us start with the first gene for D and d. STEP 1: We first determine the probability of having offspring with the recessive genotype dd given a Dd x Dd cross by drawing a monohybrid Punnet square. Out of the four possible outcomes, only one is “dd,” therefore the first monohybrid cross has a 1/4 or 25% chance of being our genotype of interest, “dd”. But be careful, your work is not yet done because you have another monohybrid cross to draw. Do not fall for the trap answer ¼ (Option B). STEP 2: Next, we can examine the probability of having offspring with the recessive genotype ee given the cross Ee x Ee. Drawing out the monohybrid cross, we can see that only one out of four possible outcomes is “ee.” Therefore, the second monohybrid cross has a 1/4 or 25% chance of being our genotype of interest, “ee”. STEP 3: Finally, we must determine the probability of both cases occurring to result in offspring with the “ddee” genotype (recessive for both traits). From the laws of probability, the probability of offspring having “ddee” is the combined probability of “dd” and “ee” occurring. This probability is the product of ¼ and ¼ and results in a chance of 1/16 . Therefore, Option D . 1/16 , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 1/2 – This option is incorrect because if both parents have the DdEe, there is a 1/4 chance that the offspring will inherit dd (1/4DD, 1/2Dd, and 1/4dd) and a 1/4 chance that the offspring will inherit ee (same logic as dd). Therefore, we multiply the probabilities to get the total probability of producing a ddee offspring. (1/4)(1/4) = 1/16 Option B. 1/4 – This option is incorrect . You might have been tempted to pick this answer after each monohybrid cross because they both resulted in a probability of 1/4. However, make sure you remember that the probability of the offspring being fully recessive (ddee) is the product of the two probabilities: (1/4)(1/4) = 1/16 Option C. 1/8 – This option is incorrect because if both parents have the DdEe, there is a 1/4 chance that the offspring will inherit dd (1/4DD, 1/2Dd, and 1/4dd) and a 1/4 chance that the offspring will inherit ee (same logic as dd). Therefore, we multiply the probabilities to get the total probability of producing a ddee offspring. (1/4)(1/4) = 1/16 Option E. 1/32 – This option is incorrect because if both parents have the DdEe, there is a 1/4 chance that the offspring will inherit dd (1/4DD, 1/2Dd, and 1/4dd) and a 1/4 chance that the offspring will inherit ee (same logic as dd). Therefore, we multiply the probabilities to get the total probability of producing a ddee offspring. (1/4)(1/4) = 1/16

question.text: Which of the following plant hormones promote fruit ripening?

explanation.concept_text: Ethylene is a gaseous hormone that promotes fruit ripening and flower production. This makes Option B , the correct answer. You might know that a ripe apple or banana will induce its surrounding fruits to also go ripe. This is due to the release of ethylene and constitutes a positive feedback loop because as the degree of ripening increases, so does the amount of ethylene being released, which causes more ripening, and so on. Ripening and flower production are important checkpoints in the life cycle of angiosperms. Ripening gives fruit a sweeter taste, stronger scent, and more vibrant colors, all of which contribute to the ultimate goal of fruit production: seed dispersal by animals. Flowers facilitate seed production by attracting pollinators , such as birds and bees, who carry out cross-pollination of plants. Ethylene also regulates plant leaves by inducing senescence (aging) and abscission (shedding) – two crucial steps in the relocation of nutrients from older parts of the plant to newer ones. Without abscission, fruit would have a very hard time dropping even when ripe, leading to decreased seed dispersal. Canadian DAT Pro Tip : Ethylene is produced naturally by plants, however, the artificial release of ethylene by humans has proven very useful for agricultural purposes.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Gibberellins – This option is incorrect because gibberellins do not induce fruit ripening. Instead, gibberellins induce seed germination and cell division (flower and stem elongation). Moreover, gibberellins are involved in the inhibition of aging in leaves – essentially serving as an antagonist to ethylene’s senescence effect. Option C. Abscisic Acid – This option is incorrect because abscisic acid does not induce fruit ripening. Instead, abscisic acid inhibits growth and induces seed dormancy. This dormancy can later be disrupted by an increase in gibberellins or by mechanistic responses to environmental cues such as temperature and light. Option D. Auxin – This option is incorrect because auxin does not induce fruit ripening. Instead, auxin stimulates the growth of plants through elongation. This is achieved by loosening cellulose fibers and increasing cell wall plasticity, which then allows for turgor pressure to expand cells to grow. Auxin is the hormone responsible for phototropism and geotropism – a plant’s ability to adjust its growth depending on light and gravity conditions, respectively. In practice, this results in the stem growing toward the light source and opposite to gravity. Option E. Cytokinin – This option is incorrect because cytokinin does not induce fruit ripening. Instead, cytokinin stimulates cell division and organ development. Additionally, cytokinin delays the aging of leaves (i.e., it inhibits senescence). Therefore, cytokinin serves as an antagonist to ethylene.

question.text: A random group of 200 black bears dissociate from a bigger population and settle in a region 100 km away. It is observed that the smaller group, along with their future generations, have a different fur type than the original population. What best describes this phenomenon?

explanation.concept_text: The question stem poses a scenario in which a subpopulation with different genetic material undergoes a change in allele frequency. This points to either gene flow or genetic drift as these are causes of change in allele frequency within a population. The key difference between gene flow and genetic drift is the group of individuals being affected. To elaborate, gene flow is the transfer of genes between two separate populations. On the other hand, genetic drift is the change of allele frequency within one small population. because they both induce a change in allele frequency within one small population. However, the bottleneck effect describes allele frequency change due to drastic or catastrophic events, which is not mentioned in the question stem. This makes Option E. Founder’s effect , a type of genetic drift, the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Gene flow – This option is incorrect because gene flow is the flow of alleles caused by individuals migrating and mating between separate populations. This question does not mention two separate populations mating with each other. Instead, this question mentions one small population being isolated (which suggests genetic drift). Gene flow increases genetic diversity, whereas the example in the question decreases genetic diversity (because a population was isolated). In summary, remember that genetic flow involves the change of allele frequencies between two populations, whereas genetic is a process that happens to one population. Option B. Hybrid vigor – This option is incorrect because hybrid vigor describes a situation where the offspring of two inbred strains experience more advantages than either parent. This superiority is caused by the reduction in harmful homozygous recessive alleles and the increase in beneficial heterozygous advantage. An example of hybrid vigor is the crossing of two inbred corn lines. Because each of the two parent lines is inbred and likely homozygous recessive for diseases or defective alleles, the crossing of the two different lines will result in offspring with a more diverse set of alleles and therefore, improved yield, size, and growth rate. The question does not provide enough information to determine whether heterosis would occur within the isolated population of the bears (e.g., fitness of a hybrid offspring within the isolated population). Option C. Bottleneck Effect – This option is incorrect because the bottleneck effect is a random change in allele frequencies that happens after the occurrence of catastrophic events. While bottleneck and founder’s effect are both examples of genetic drift, there is a distinct difference between them; in a bottleneck scenario, the change in allele frequency is caused by a drastic or catastrophic reduction in population (such as earthquakes, floods, overhunting, deforestation, etc.) In this question, the change in allele frequency was caused by a migratory event – not a catastrophic event. Therefore, the result could not have been the bottleneck effect. Option D. Outbreeding – This option is incorrect because outbreeding describes the mating of unrelated individuals. Specifically, outbreeding involves the transfer of different genes between individuals and, therefore, the creation of new allele combinations. Since the 200 individuals within the isolated group are genetically similar (same fur type), this exchange of different genes could not have occurred.

question.text: The first intermediate formed by the process of glycolysis is __________.

explanation.concept_text: For the test, you do not need to memorize every single intermediate and enzyme involved in cellular respiration, but you should know the major steps. Let us briefly review the key steps below. Things will be more intuitive if we understand why they happen in a certain way. Focus on the overall process and the three main goals of glycolysis: 1) Breakdown of glucose to two pyruvates to be used in cellular respiration, 2) production of two ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation, and 3) generation of NADH (electron acceptors) to be used later in the electron transport chain. In both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, Glycolysis takes place in the cytoplasm of the cell – NOT inside mitochondria. consists of two important phases: energy investment and energy payoff phase. As seen in the figure below, the energy investment phase consumes ATP to phosphorylate glucose, trapping it in the cell as glucose-6-phosphate . After this intermediate is isomerized to fructose, it is phosphorylated again to form fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. This is important as this step commits itself to glycolysis because the 6-carbon molecule is at its highest energy. The remaining steps are part of the energy payoff phase as G3P is converted to pyruvate. Based on this information, Option D , Glucose-6-phosphate is the correct answer. Canadian DAT Pro Tip : The intermediate substrates will also phosphorylate ADP to ATP hence this ATP production is known as substrate-level phosphorylation . Our net result is 2 ATP, 2 pyruvates, and 2 NADH. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Acetyl-CoA – This option is incorrect because acetyl-CoA is NOT an intermediate formed during glycolysis. Acetyl-CoA is the product of pyruvate oxidation – a process that occurs after glycolysis. Once formed, acetyl-CoA enters the citric acid cycle (aka Krebs cycle) and combines with oxaloacetate to form a six-carbon molecule that further carries the cycle. Option B. Pyruvate – This option is incorrect because pyruvate is NOT the first intermediate that is formed during glycolysis. Instead, pyruvate is the end product of glycolysis. Under aerobic conditions (oxygen is present), the pyruvate molecule will be transported into the mitochondria, where it will undergo pyruvate oxidation to be converted into acetyl-CoA. In contrast, if oxygen is not present (anaerobic conditions) pyruvate will undergo fermentation (reduction of pyruvate to lactic acid) to regenerate NAD+, a crucial electron acceptor for the next round of glycolysis. Option C. Oxaloacetate – This option is incorrect because oxaloacetate is NOT formed during glycolysis. Oxaloacetate is an intermediate formed during the citric acid cycle (aka Krebs cycle), which occurs after glycolysis. During the citric acid cycle, oxaloacetate (a four-carbon molecule) reacts with acetyl-CoA to form citrate (a six-carbon molecule). After a series of reactions, the citric acid cycle regenerates an oxaloacetate molecule, and the cycle starts all over again. Option E. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate – This option is incorrect because glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is an intermediate formed immediately after fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is formed. Since we are looking for the first intermediate in glycolysis, we must choose an option produced directly from molecules of glucose.

question.text: Which of the following is a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme RuBisCo?

explanation.concept_text: The Calvin cycle , also known as the light-independent reaction of photosynthesis, takes place in the stroma of plant cell chloroplasts and is a series of chemical reactions that convert carbon dioxide (captured from the atmosphere) into glucose to be used for energy by plants. The Calvin cycle is split into three main steps: 1) Carbon fixation 2) Reduction, and 3) Regeneration. Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase, more commonly known as RuBisCo , is the enzyme that drives carbon fixation. It is so vital to life on Earth that it is the most abundant protein on the planet. Despite its significant importance to life on Earth, RuBisCo has a flaw: under high oxygen concentrations, RuBisCo can fix oxygen instead of carbon, an inefficient process known as photorespiration . When plant cells close their stomata to conserve water, oxygen becomes much more available as a substrate to RuBisCo and acts as a competitive inhibitor to carbon dioxide, resulting in photorespiration. This process consumes energy and releases carbon dioxide, effectively undoing some of the work of photosynthesis. In addition, the binding of oxygen to RuBisCo yields a product that is of no use to the plant cell since it cannot contribute to the Calvin cycle. Therefore, Option B , Oxygen , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Carbon Dioxide – This option is incorrect . Not only is carbon dioxide NOT a competitive inhibitor to RuBisCo, but in fact, carbon dioxide is the only substrate that allows the Calvin cycle to continue normally. RuBisCo uses carbon dioxide to carboxylate ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate (RuBP) into a six-carbon compound and allows carbon fixation to proceed. Option C. Glucose – This option is incorrect because glucose is not a competitive inhibitor of RuBisCo. Moreover, glucose does not even directly interact with RuBisCo. Instead, glucose is one of the byproducts of a normal Calvin cycle (i.e., carbon fixation occurs instead of oxygen fixation). Glucose is generated after RuBisCo participates in the cycle. Option D. Water – This option is incorrect because water is not a competitive inhibitor to RuBisCo. Water is essential for photosynthesis as it is an essential part of the light-dependent reaction to split water molecules into oxygen (O 2 ) and hydrogen ions (H + ) which are then used during photosynthesis. Option E. Magnesium – This option is incorrect . While magnesium ions (Mg 2+ ) are involved in the activity of RuBisCo they do not serve as competitive inhibitors to RuBisCo. Instead, magnesium ions serve as a cofactor in the activation of RuBisCo. Recall that a cofactor is a non-protein molecule that assists an enzyme carry out its function. Not only is magnesium not a competitive inhibitor to RuBisCo, but as a cofactor, it enhances RuBisCo’s intended purpose: carbon fixation. Magnesium is also the central atom within the chlorophyll molecule. Therefore, not only is magnesium not a competitive inhibitor to RuBisCo, but it serves as a vital part in the successful capture of light energy for photosynthesis.

question.text: How does the DNA of daughter cells compare to that of the parent cell following mitosis?

options.label: A.
options.text: Identical and half the amount of DNA

options.label: B.
options.text: Not identical and half the amount of DNA

options.label: C.
options.text: Identical and the same amount of DNA

options.label: D.
options.text: Not identical and the same amount of DNA

options.label: E.
options.text: Identical and four times the amount of DNA

correct_answer_text: Identical and the same amount of DNA

explanation.concept_text: There are multiple reasons why cell division is crucial to life on Earth. In unicellular organisms, cell division is the primary method of reproduction. In multicellular organisms, one fertilized egg (zygote) undergoes millions upon millions of cell divisions to grow into an organism composed of trillions of cells. For an organism to fully develop, two types of cell divisions are needed: meiosis and mitosis. Meiosis exclusively creates haploid sperm and egg cells (gametes), whereas mitosis creates diploid cells for cell growth and development and is used by all somatic cells (any cell other than a gamete, such as muscle, neuron, liver, and stomach cells). Meiosis is only used to create the gametes that fuse to form a zygote, however, once the zygote is formed, mitosis takes over and serves as the sole driver of cell growth and development. When it comes to handling genetic information, mitosis and meiosis serve different roles. Mitosis creates genetically identical daughter cells and discards cells that fail to exactly replicate the parent cell’s DNA, whereas meiosis intentionally increases genetic diversity with every new cell division. Because of crossing over , each of the millions of cells created by meiosis is genetically unique (contains a unique set of alleles compared to the parent cell or other daughter cells). Moreover, meiosis is a reduction division because every daughter cell contains half the amount of genetic information (haploid) compared to the parent cell. On the other hand, mitosis creates an exact copy of the parent cell’s entire DNA (diploid). During the S phase of interphase (before mitosis occurs), each chromosome undergoes replication resulting in two identical copies called sister chromatids, which are linked together at a region called the centromere. During the metaphase stage of mitosis, these pairs of identical sister chromatids line up at the center of the cell, and during anaphase, the identical sister chromatids are pulled apart and separated from each other. Therefore, the two daughter cells share the exact same DNA as the parent cell and in the same quantity. This question mentions that mitosis is taking place, which allows us to deduce that the daughter cells must be somatic cells (non-gamete), diploid, and contain the exact same copy of the organism’s entire genome. As such, Option C , Identical and the same amount of DNA, is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Identical and half the amount of DNA – This option is incorrect because two daughter cells resulting from mitosis will have the same amount of DNA. Recall that during mitosis, the total number of chromosomes in the parent cell doubles from 46 to 92 (in the case of humans). After cytokinesis occurs (separation into two cells), the 92 chromosomes are equally shared between the two daughter cells. Therefore, at the end of mitosis, each daughter cell has 46 chromosomes. Only meiosis reduces the amount of DNA during cell division. Option B. Not identical and half the amount of DNA – This option is incorrect because mitosis creates daughter cells resulting with the same amount of DNA while also sharing identical DNA. Recall that only meiosis—not mitosis—results in non-identical daughter cells because it is the only process that involves chromosomal crossing over. Moreover, meiosis carries out reductional cell division because a diploid parent cell gives rise to haploid daughter cells — in other words, half the amount of DNA. However, this question is asking about mitosis, which will always give rise to two genetically identical cells (i.e., identical in both amount and sequence of genes). Therefore, this option is incorrect. Option D. Not identical and the same amount of DNA – This option is incorrect because two daughter cells resulting from mitosis will have identical DNA. Recall that during the S phase of interphase, each chromosome undergoes replication and consists of two identical copies called sister chromatids, which are linked together at a region called the centromere. During metaphase, these pairs of identical sister chromatids line up at the center of the cell, and during anaphase, the identical sister chromatids are pulled apart and separated from each other. Therefore, the two daughter cells share the exact same DNA. Only meiosis alters the DNA of the daughter cells compared to the parent cells. Option E. Identical and four times the amount of DNA – This option is incorrect because two daughter cells resulting from mitosis will have the same amount of DNA – NOT four times. For mitosis to produce a four-fold difference in the amount of DNA between daughter cells, an error would have to occur during cell division. Even if such a rare mistake were to occur, it would likely be flagged by one of the checkpoints of cell division. Therefore, such a discrepancy in the amount of DNA between two daughter cells is highly unlikely to occur.

question.text: A scientist accidentally mixes together bacterial, fungal, and plant cells in a petri dish. He will be able to correctly identify each of these cells by closely examining the composition of their __________.

explanation.concept_text: This question tests your knowledge of the various types of cell walls and the molecules that compose them. Recall that plants are not the only organisms with cell wall structures in their cells; cell walls are also found in bacteria, fungi, and archaea. In prokaryotes, bacterial cell walls are made up of peptidoglycan , whereas archaea cell walls are made up of polysaccharides . Within the eukaryotes, plant cell walls are made up of cellulose , whereas fungal cell walls are made up of chitin . This question is essentially asking for a cell component found in bacteria, fungi, and plants, but with enough differences in that component to distinguish the three from each other. The cell wall is the only cell component that matches these criteria. Therefore, Option B , Cell wall , is the correct answer. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Nucleus – This option is incorrect . Bacteria notably lack a nuclear membrane, and therefore, lack a true nucleus. Instead, bacterial cells hold their genetic information as one circular DNA molecule in an irregularly shaped region called the nucleoid. Because there is no nuclear membrane, bacterial transcription and translation occur simultaneously in the cytosol. Fungal and plant cells both contain a nucleus, therefore, the scientist could not correctly distinguish the two by examining the nucleus alone. Option C. Ribosomes – This option is incorrect because the presence of ribosomes cannot distinguish between all three cell types mentioned above. Ribosomes are the polypeptide-producing machinery found in archaea, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes. As the primary site of protein synthesis, ribosomes play a crucial role in the proper function of most of life on earth, including bacteria, fungi, and plants. Bacterial ribosomes can be distinguished from eukaryotic ribosomes because of the difference in size (70S vs 80S, respectively). However, fungi and plant cells are both eukaryotic, therefore, ribosomes cannot be used to distinguish between the two (since they both have 80S ribosomes), making this answer choice incorrect. Option D. Glucose – This option is incorrect . Plants produce glucose via photosynthesis, whereas bacteria and fungi break down glucose via glycolysis. While all three cell types use glucose for crucial cell functions, glucose is NOT a structural component in any of them. Glucose is too universal of a molecule to life, rendering it a bad identifying factor when comparing bacteria, fungi, and plant cells. Option E. Mitochondria – This option is incorrect because bacteria do NOT have mitochondria in their structure. Remember that bacteria are prokaryotic, which means they lack membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria. Instead, bacteria rely primarily on glycolysis or produce their ATP through an electron transport chain embedded within the cell’s own cell membrane (as opposed to the inner membrane of mitochondria). Fungi and animal cells are both eukaryotic and have mitochondria; the scientist would not be able to distinguish between the two solely based on the presence of mitochondria, thus making this option incorrect.
